questions.text: A 10-year-old male patient presented with macular lesions on the trunk as shown in the image. On stroking a macular lesion with a blunt object, there is erythema around the reddish-brown macules. Which of the following diseases would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The skin reaction depicted above is Darier’s sign, which is seen in cutaneous mastocytosis.

Cutaneous mastocytosis, the most common among them being urticaria pigmentosa, presents with hyperpigmented macules. The lesions have numerous mast cells. Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. However, Darier's sign is not highly specific to mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia of neonates.

Note: Pseudo-Darier’s sign is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma, and piloerection of the muscle is responsible for the sign.

Mastocytosis is an acquired condition where there is a massive increase in the number of mast cells in the skin and other tissues. They are further classified by WHO as:

  • Cutaneous mastocytosis
    • Maculopapular cutaneous mastocytosis or urticaria pigmentosa (most common)
    • Mastocytoma
    • Diffuse cutaneous mastocytosis
  • Systemic mastocytosis

Histopathology of skin lesions in urticaria pigmentosa shows mast cell infiltrates predominantly around blood vessels and skin appendages in the papillary dermis. Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin (H&E)–stained sections. Special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules. Stains for mast cells:

  • Toluidine blue
  • Giemsa
  • Tryptase
  • Leder stain (Chloracetate esterase)
  • CD 117

The image below shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue.

 

Urticaria pigmentosa is common in 20-40 years age group and is characterized by numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques or nodules. They are in symmetrical distribution anywhere on the body except the palms and soles and seen maximum on the trunk and thighs. The lesions are positive for Darier's sign.

Treatment: Second-generation antihistaminics like cetirizine, fexofenadine, etc are the mainstay treatment. Other therapies include topical corticosteroids and photochemotherapy.

Other options: 

Option B: Cholinergic urticaria appears when the person is sweating after exercise or when the core body temperature is elevated and the patient develops pinpoint wheals. This is mediated by acetylcholine released by the sympathetic fibres of the eccrine sweat glands.

Option C: Chronic idiopathic urticaria: Urticaria with nonspecific etiology, lasting for more than 6 weeks.

Option D: Allergic contact dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. Patch testing can confirm the specific allergen involved. Long-term treatment of allergic contact dermatitis involves avoidance of the allergen.

Oral candidiasis (thrush) is categorized as WHO stage 3.

questions.text: The following image shows the boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection. The inferior boundary marked as ‘A’ denotes _____.
questions.solution:
The space of axillary lymph node dissection is inferiorly bounded by the angular vein (marked as ‘A’).

Boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection (ALND):

  • Superior - Axillary vein
  • Lateral - Thoracodorsal pedicle
  • Medial - Costoclavicular ligament (Halstead ligament)
  • Inferior - Angular vein    

Indications for ALND:

  1. Locally advanced (T4a, b, c) or inflammatory breast cancer
  2. Metastatic disease in axillary lymph node(s) proven by needle biopsy, clinically palpable or nonpalpable nodes which are abnormal on imaging

Structures preserved during ALND:

  1. Lateral and medial pectoral nerves
  2. Thoracodorsal pedicle

questions.text: The true statement about the placenta shown in the image is

choices.text: Villi are attached to the myometrium
Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa
Villi do not touch the myometrium

questions.solution:
The true statement is the villi invade the myometrium.

The given image shows placenta increta.

There are 3 variants of placenta accreta syndrome. They are

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male on multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg for the last 7 days. The patient gives a history of similar episodes in the past which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, Analgesics, and Hypnotics.

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome).

questions.text: The bullet fired from the firearm shown in the image will have
questions.solution:
The image shows a rifled firearm.

The bullet fired from a rifled firearm will be a spinning projectile on stable course.

Bullet fired from a smooth bore firearm will be a tumbling projectile with unstable course.

questions.text: A 45 year old iron smelter, presents to the OPD with history of rice water diarrhoea. The image shows the clinical finding that the doctor notes during examination. Which of the following clinical features would be consistent with the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning. Tremors are consistent with a diagnosis of arsenic poisoning which should be suspected in a patient of with Aldrich Mees lines, red velvety mucosa, and rice water stools.

Hyperpyrexia, Hyperpigmentation, and Anorexia are associated features.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: A  patient presented with acute worsening of edema of the left hand, which was present for the past 5 years. Her surgical history was relevant for a radical mastectomy with radiation therapy for left-sided breast carcinoma. On examination, the limb appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Stewart–Treves syndrome.

The development of angiosarcoma after a combination of postmastectomy lymphedema and radiation therapy is known as Stewart–Treves syndrome. It can arise de-novo or in association with post-mastectomy lymphedema. It presents with acute worsening of edema with subcutaneous nodules which are hemorrhagic or ulcerative.

Treatment is preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation of arm). The prognosis is poor.

Option A: Tietze syndrome is an inflammatory condition characterized by chest pain and swelling of the cartilage around the ribs at the costochondral junction. 

Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that affects the muscle tissue, mostly in children and adolescents.

Option D: Milroy's disease is a familial disease, caused by congenital abnormalities in the lymphatic system. Disruption of the normal drainage of lymph leads to fluid accumulation and hypertrophy of soft tissues.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the procedure given below for chronic pancreatitis, except:

choices.text: Refractory pain to analgesia is an indication
It is done if the diameter of the main pancreatic duct is greater than 8 mm

questions.solution:
The image shows the distal resection of the pancreatic tail with end-to-end pancreaticojejunostomy, i.e., Duval procedure. It is done if the diameter of the main pancreatic duct is greater than 6mm.

Duval procedure is one of the drainage procedures done for chronic pancreatitis. Refractory pain to analgesia is the common indication for this procedure.

This procedure is outdated and not in use due to low improvement rates. Restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas is common due to progressive scarring. It is now only used in resectable tumors of the body or the tail of the pancreas.

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

questions.solution:
The given image shows Burking - a combination of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia.


Lynching - Putting a person to death by mob action for an alleged offence without a legal trial.

Choking - blockage of the upper airways by some foreign body, but variably also used for manual strangulation.

questions.solution:
The image shows Babcocks Forceps.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with oral ulcers and bullae over the mucosa and skin. On examination, the bullae are flaccid and filled with clear fluid. Histopathology of the lesion shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the suprabasal splitting of the epidermis (acantholysis) giving rise to the row of tombstones appearance. This is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus. It involves the mucosa and skin. Autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 are present.

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.

Variants of pemphigus:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Pemphigus vegetans
  • Pemphigus foliaceus - autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.
  • Pemphigus erythematosus
  • Paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Identify the structure marked X in the image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X is the C-cells or the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland.

The C-cells are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They secrete calcitonin.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

Option D: Hürthle cells are oncocytes with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and a vesicular nucleus with a large nucleolus found in the thyroid arising from follicular cells. They are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis, Hürthle cell adenoma and Hürthle cell carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: While performing the following pediatric emergency procedure being performed on the model of an infant, which of the following indicates a wrong technique?

choices.text: Compression : Breath ratio should ideally be 30:2
Fingers should be lifted off the chest to allow effective recoil between compressions
Efficiency of chest compression should be assessed with brachial pulse periodically
Alternatively, the two thumb technique is equally effective

questions.solution:
The image shows infant CPR. Fingers should not be lifted off the chest between compressions.

The thumbs or the tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths in a minute.i.e 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if second rescuer arrives)

In infants, the brachial pulse should be assessed. (For children aged one to adolescence, the pulse should be checked at the carotid artery)

The two-finger technique and two thumb technique are considered to be equally effective.

questions.solution:
Image C depicts Walter Reed and the Rabies virus they are nowhere related to each other. Walter Reed was known for discovering that Yellow fever is transmitted by mosquitoes.

Image A shows John Snow and microscopic picture of Vibrio Cholera.
John snow was well known for his work in field of anaesthesia and also he was the one who first discovered the source of cholera outbreak (i.e. cholera is a water borne infection)

questions.text: Which clinical symptom will not be present in the patient whose X Ray is shown?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray is of eagle syndrome. A patient with this condition will not have ear discharge.

Eagle syndrome, also called kerato-stylohyoidal syndrome, is characterised by an elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament.

Etiology: Usually, this condition is seen post-tonsillectomy or post pharyngeal trauma. It is more common in Females (3:1).

Clinical Presentation:

  • Commonly bilateral
  • Presentation 1: Classic Eagle syndrome
    • Dull and persistent pharyngeal pain often referred to the ear.
    • Pain exacerbated by rotation of the head.
    • A palpable mass or a bulge in the tonsillar fossa.
    • Other associated symptoms like dysphagia, foreign body sensation, tinnitus and cervicofacial pain may be seen.
  • Presentation 2: Stylocarotid syndrome
    • Compression of the internal or external carotid artery by medially or laterally rotated styloid process.

Treatment: Styloidectomy in those not responding to conservative treatment with analgesics.

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the oesophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding?
questions.solution: The given images showing an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy and apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus on barium swallow are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. The characteristic histopathological finding in this condition are nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 4.

questions.text: A child presents with a history of severe sunburns just after a few minutes in the sun.  Severe freckling is noted in the sun-exposed areas as shown below. The autosomal recessive condition responsible for this is due to:
questions.solution:
The image and history point to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by Defective Nucleotide Excision repair.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure. This leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

In XP the skin is normal at birth and has a three-stage progression:

  • Diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle-like areas over the sun-exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.
  • The second stage is characterized by poikiloderma. This results in skin atrophy, telangiectasias with mottled hyperpigmentation, and hyperpigmentation.
  • In the third stage appearance of cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma. 

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin. XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.

Other options:

Option A: Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ) is seen in Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID).

Option C: Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER) leads to MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP).

Option D: Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR) causes Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

questions.text: According to the American Society for Reproductive Medicine classification of Mullerian duct anomalies, the uterine anomaly in the image falls under which class.
questions.solution:
The image given falls under Class II.

It is an image of Unicornuate uterus in which the formation of the uterus and fallopian tube occurs entirely from one Mullerian duct due to developmental arrest of other Mullerian duct.

The American Society for Reproductive Medicine classification is as follows:

  • Class I - Mullerian agenesis or hypoplasia
  • Class II - Unicornuate uterus or uterus unicornis
  • Class III - Uterus didelphys
  • Class IV - Bicornuate uterus
  • Class V - Septate uterus
  • Class VI - Arcuate uterus
  • Class VII - Diethylstilbestrol related anomalies

questions.text: A 68 year old man was treated with chlorthalidone, furosemide, Ramipril, acetazolamide, metoprolol, insulin and atorvastatin for heart failure. Now he presents with right sided hearing loss. Examination shows Weber’s test localised to left ear and Rinne’s test shows AC>BC in both ears. The responsible offending agent acts most likely in which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from sensory neural hearing loss. This is due to the adverse effect of IV furosemide used during his heart failure treatment. Furosemide acts on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle which is marked by option B in the illustration.

Other options:

Carbonic anhydrase acts on the PCT. It is used for glaucoma, pseudotumor cerebri, metabolic alkalosis and cystine stone prevention.

Thiazides act on the DCT. It is used for treatment of hypertension and chronic edema.

ADH receptor antagonists like Tolvaptan act in medullary CT. Used for treating hyponatremia

Other common ototoxic drugs are:

  1. Antibiotics like Aminoglycosides ( gentamicin > tobramycin > amikacin > neomycin), erythromycin, tetracyclines.
  2. Chemotherapeutic agents like Cisplatin, Bleomycin and Nitrogen mustard.
  3. High dose aspirin, acetaminophen and NSAID’s
  4. Antimalarials like quinine and quinidine
  5. Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors like Sildenafil

questions.text: The EEG pattern seen above is suggestive of the person being:
questions.solution:
This EEG pattern is seen in Stage 2 of NREM Sleep.

In the EEG shown above, symmetric synchronous theta rhythms with 12-15/sec spindles, vertex sharp waves, POSTS (positive occipital sharp transients of sleep) and K complexes are present. The appearance of sleep spindles in 12-15/sec range is a hallmark of sleep onset.

Sleep spindles are sudden bursts of oscillatory brain activity generated in the reticular nucleus of the thalamus that occur during stage 2 of light sleep.

Vertex Waves first occur in late drowsiness as non-REM sleep develops (Stage 1) and are the first EEG pattern to occur that is unique to sleep.

POSTS are positive sharp deflections in the theta range that occur during sleep and drowsiness.

K-complex occurs during stage 2 of NREM sleep. It is the "largest event in healthy human EEG". They are more frequent in the first sleep cycles.

questions.text: The device shown in the image is used in the treatment of-
questions.solution:
The image shows a mirror box used in the treatment of Phantom Limb Disorder.

The mirror box was invented by Vilayanur S. Ramachandran to help alleviate phantom limb pain, in which patients feel they still have a limb after having it amputated.

The  patient inserts his limb into one hole and the "phantom" limb into the other. When viewed from an angle, the brain is tricked into seeing two complete limbs.

The wider use of mirrors in this way is known as mirror therapy or mirror visual feedback (MVF).

questions.text: Identify the yoke muscle for the muscle marked below?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is left superior oblique, hence the corresponding yoke muscle will be right inferior rectus. (Its left eye because of the presence of medial septum to the right to eyeball) 

Yoke muscles are contralateral synergists. They are a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements.

Examples are:

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right IO and Left SR

questions.text: Which component of the National AIDS Control Program does the image signify?

choices.text: PPTCT (Prevention of Parent To Child Transmission)

questions.solution:
The logo signifies Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission(PPTCT). The program was launched in 2002

Under this program pregnant women are provided with counselling and testing in the Integrated Counselling and Testing Centre (ICTC).

This program aims to prevent perinatal transmission of HIV from an infected pregnant mother to her newborn baby.

questions.text: A 32-year-old dental hygienist presents to the clinic with swelling and redness of the right index finger (as shown below). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Herpetic whitlow, caused by HSV infection. It can occur as a complication of primary oral or genital herpes.  It is an occupational hazard in dentists and other health care workers with repeated exposure to infected secretions. It is typically affects the fingers or thumbs. It starts as small, clear vesicles initially form individually, then merge and become cloudy.

Cellulitis,  Felon, Paronychia are all bacterial infections and do not present with initial clear fluid filled vesicles.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given X-ray finding seen?
questions.solution:
The given image is a barium swallow X-ray showing a feline esophagus suggestive of reflux esophagitis.

The feline esophagus is also known as esophageal shiver. These folds are 1-2 mm thick and run horizontally around the entire circumference of the esophageal lumen. It is thought to be due to the contraction of the muscularis mucosae of the esophagus. This results in the shortening of the esophagus and the bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen. 

The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic esophagus. 

It can also be seen in hiatus hernia and eosinophilic esophagitis. Here, the folds are permanent and associated with strictures.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: The use of device give in the image is contraindicated in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Non - Vigorous Baby with Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

questions.solution:
The image shows a Bag Valve Mask device and its use is contraindicated in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia.

In the case of a nonvigorous baby with meconium aspiration syndrome, there is no contraindication to use the bag and mask ventilation.

ACOG no longer recommends to routinely suction nonvigorous infants as it delays in providing bag-mask ventilation.

questions.text: A 40-year-man presents with hematuria, polyuria, and hypertension. The resected kidney is as seen below. All are associated with this condition except ______.

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen
Portal fibrosis and proliferation of portal bile ducts

questions.solution:
Clinical history and gross image suggest that the patient has autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). They are associated with cysts in liver, spleen, and pancreas; berry aneurysms; and mitral valve prolapse.

Note: 

Patients with autosomal-recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD

  • Autosomal-dominant disorder
  • Multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure
  • 40% have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease)
  • Cysts in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms arise in the circle of Willis à subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1 and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2
  • Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: What is the ideal retention period for the method of excreta disposal shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a septic tank, it’s a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment. The ideal retention period for septic tank is 24hrs.

Capacity of 20-30 gallons per person is recommended for household septic tanks. Length of the tank is twice the breadth.

Minimum air-space of 30cm should be there between the level of liquid in the tank and under-surface of the cover.

questions.text:
A first-year psychiatry resident gets a call regarding one of his patients who has been brought to the ER with high-grade fever and pharyngitis. The patient was started on clozapine two weeks back for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. His oral examination reveals the following picture. What would be the appropriate management?
  1. Stop clozapine
  2. Reduce the dose of clozapine
  3. Administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor
  4. Switch to another antipsychotic medication
  5. Give antibiotics
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever and pharyngitis and the simultaneous development of oral ulcers (image) in a patient on clozapine is suggestive of drug-induced agranulocytosis. The treatment is to stop clozapine immediately, administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF), and start empirical antibiotics.

Agranulocytosis is a rare, but fatal complication of clozapine. It is defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) < 500/mm3, or white blood cell (WBC) count < 2000/mm3. It can initially manifest as a local infection with high-grade fever, sore throat, oral and perianal ulcerations.

These symptoms appear rapidly within days to weeks following initiation of drug therapy.

Clozapine is generally considered to be more effective than other antipsychotic drugs and is often used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia (poor treatment response to 2 or more antipsychotic drugs). Hence, a switch from clozapine to another (less effective) antipsychotic drug is not done in a patient with drug-induced agranulocytosis.

questions.text: When found in water source, the organism in the image indicates remote contamination of water. The organism is:
questions.solution:
Clostridium perfringens is an indicator of remote contamination of water. Whereas, Faecal streptococci indicates recent contamination of water.

E. coli is the most important bacterial indicator of water quality.

Multiple tube method is test to estimate the Most Probable Number (MPN) of coliform organisms in 100 ml water sample

The test is done by inoculating measured quantities of water sample in MacConkey's Lactose Bile Salt broth with Bromocresol blue as the indicator.

The given image depicts placenta succenturiata in which one or more small lobes of placenta may be placed at a distance from main placental margin.

Its complications are -

  • Postpartum haemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Uterine sepsis
  • Polyp formation

questions.text: Which of the following risk factor is most commonly associated with the development of the condition seen in the following CT?
questions.solution:
The image shows an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.

Though medial degeneration is the most common pathology associated with ascending aortic aneurysms, and atherosclerosis is the condition most frequently associated with aneurysms of the descending thoracic aorta, since atherosclerosis is not there in the options, Hypertension would be the next best choice.

Although smoking, obesity and hereditary factors have an impact they are not the most commonly associated factors for causing TAA (Thoracic Aortic Aneurysms).

World Hypertension Day is a day designated and initiated by The World Hypertension League to increase the awareness of hypertension. It is observed on the 17th May 2019.

questions.text: On clinical examination, you find sensory loss in the region indicated. You would expect a deficit in:

choices.text: No associated motor weakness will be present

questions.solution:
The image shows Regimental Badge Sign. It is seen in Axillary nerve injuries. Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid which is responsible for abduction 15-90 degrees.

Other options:

  • Initiation of Abduction is not affected as it is caused by supraspinatus.
  • Overhead abduction is the function of serratus anterior and trapezius muscles and hence is not affected.
  • The posterior branch of axillary nerve supplies, teres minor and posterior of deltoid and terminates as the cutaneous nerve of armwhich supplies the skin over the lower half of deltoid. Deltoid muscle palsy can lead to loss of rounded contour of shoulder and palsy of lateral cutaneous nerve of arm are other significant features.

questions.text: A 20 year old primi with history of 3 months of  amenorrhoea came for routine antenatal check up. The USG done is suggestive of which fetal anomaly-
questions.solution:
The USG shows characteristic triangular facial appearance and shower cap sign pointing towards acrania.

Acrania - the absence of the cranium, with protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue.

This anomaly is more prevalent in first birth and about 70% of fetuses are females.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray image depicts Chilaiditi sign, characterized by the anterior interposition of the colon between the liver and the right hemidiaphragm, which can mimic air under the diaphragm, leading to pseudo-pneumoperitoneum.

Chilaiditi sign is typically an incidental finding on imaging and is most often asymptomatic. However, when associated with symptoms such as abdominal pain and distension, it is referred to as Chilaiditi syndrome. 

An erect X-ray showing this sign may mislead clinicians into suspecting pneumoperitoneum, prompting unnecessary urgent surgical intervention, which is not required. To differentiate Chilaiditi syndrome from true pneumoperitoneum, a contrast-enhanced CT or a left lateral decubitus radiograph can be performed. In the left lateral decubitus view, distended colonic loops with haustral markings will be visible, showing that the air is within the bowel and not in the peritoneal cavity. 

Other conditions with the Chilaiditi sign are curvilinear pulmonary collapse, distended viscus, omental fat, and apposition of gas-distended bowel loops mimicking the double-wall sign.

Below is the chest X-ray and CT showing the presence of herniated bowel loops under the diaphragm.

Other options:

Option A: The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows free intraperitoneal gas which is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. The presence of free intra-abdominal gas almost always indicates perforation of a hollow viscus. Free intraperitoneal gas is also detectable under the hemidiaphragm on an erect chest X-ray as given below. 

Option B: The existence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum is referred to as pneumomediastinum. Gas may originate from the peritoneal cavity, lungs, trachea, central bronchi, oesophagus, or peritoneal cavity and travel to the neck or abdomen via the mediastinum.  Spinnaker sign (also called angel wing sign) is a radiographic sign seen in neonates with pneumomediastinum. The pressure from the collected gas displaces the two lobes of the thymic tissue upward and laterally from its normal position. This results in large, wedge-shaped opacities on radiograph resembling the spinnaker headsails of a boat.  Other signs of pneumomediastinum are the V sign of Naclerio and continuous diaphragm sign. 

Below is a chest X-ray showing spinnaker sign and CT showing the presence of pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia, jaundice and splenomegaly shows pincer cells. Which protein deficiency is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution: Pincer cell or mushroom cell is seen in hereditary spherocytosis associated with deficiency of cytoskeletal protein band 3.

questions.text: You notice the following lesion in the forearm of an otherwise normal newborn. The lesion is caused because of:

choices.text: A viral infection transmitted from mother to the fetus
A bacterial infection transmitted from the mother to the fetus
Vigorous in utero sucking upon the affected part
An autoimmune condition in the newborn

questions.solution:
The image shows Sucking Blisters.
Sucking blisters are caused due to vigorous in utero sucking on the affected part.

They are usually present upon the upper-limb.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 32 year old male presents to the clinic with the following facial lesion. Upon probing there is yellowish sulfur granular discharge. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Cervicofacial actinomycosis.
It presents as a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulphur granules.

The treatment of choice is Penicillin.

Doxycycline and clindamycin are used in case of penicillin allergy.

questions.text: The end of isovolumetric expansion is marked by the point:
questions.solution:
Isovolumetric expansion is the phase from closure of aortic valve to the point when the mitral valve opens.

Mitral valve opening is marked by point C in the image. Hence that marks the end of isovolumetric expansion. Correspondingly, the LV volume can be see to be unchanged during this phase.

Also, isovolumetric relaxation phase is represented by the T wave in an ECG.

Thus, opening of mitral valve corresponds to end of T wave in an ECG.

questions.text: The microscopic appearance of cervical mucus in the given image is seen in which phase of menstrual cycle:

choices.text: All the phases of menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
This microscopic appearance is seen in proliferative phase or oestrogenic phase of menstrual cycle.

This test is called Fern test.

Fern test - During proliferative or oestrogenic phase, a specimen of cervical mucus is spread on a glass slide and allowed to dry. On viewing under low-power microscope, it shows characteristic pattern of fern formation. This ferning is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the cervical mucus secreted under oestrogen effect. This reaction disappears under progesterone influence after ovulation.

questions.text: The image depicts the quantitative test for fetomaternal hemorrhage. What inference can be derived from this test?

choices.text: Fetal RBCs are washed out and maternal RBCs are red
Maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are washed out and few immature RBCs are alone red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are red and few immature RBCs are washed out

questions.solution:
The test shown is the Kleihauer-Betke test. The test shows that the maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are red. This is because the fetal RBCs are resistant to acid digestion.

Principle of this test is that the fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A in the maternal erythrocytes.

Kleihauer–Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation. The reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as ghosts. These fetal cells are counted per 50 low-power fields. If there are 80 fetal erythrocytes in 50 low-power fields in maternal peripheral blood films, it represents a transplacental hemorrhage to the extent of 4 mL of fetal blood. 10 µg of anti-D is required for every 1 mL of fetal whole blood or 0.5 mL of fetal RBCs.

Fetomaternal hemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin F or by fetal levels of hemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed an injury to the ligaments commonly referred to as the 'unhappy triad'. Which of the following ligaments are involved?

choices.text: Posterior cruciate ligament and lateral meniscus
Anterior cruciate ligament and medial meniscus
Anterior and posterior horns of lateral meniscus

questions.solution:
The unhappy triad of the knee involves:

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the test shown in the image.

choices.text: < 5 mm of moisture - severe Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Fluorescein dye test is an alternative

questions.solution:
The image shows a Schirmer’s test being performed. It is measured after 5 minutes, not 10 minutes.

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with the following lesions. DNA analysis from tissue samples for T-cell receptor analysis showed clonal rearrangements of the T-cell receptor genes. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with the characteristic investigation of T-cell receptor analysis showing clonal rearrangement of the T-cell receptor (TCR) genes is diagnostic of Mycosis fungoides.

Mycosis fungoides is characterized by erythematous, polymorphic patches and plaques which are fine, scaly, and slightly atrophic (wrinkled) usually involving limb/girdle, breast, and especially the buttock area.

Analysis of TCR genes is now a standard approach that has diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic implications. It consists of the analysis of DNA from tissue samples for the detection of clonal rearrangements of the TCR genes as a marker of a monoclonal T‐cell population. T‐cell clones can be detected in a proportion (70% overall) of skin biopsies from patients with early‐stage disease and are almost invariable in patients with later stages of the disease.

Option A: Follicular mucinosis consists of boggy cutaneous plaques showing follicular prominence and histological evidence of mucinous degeneration of the hair follicles. It is often associated with an atypical pilotropic T‐cell infiltrate.

Option B: Bowen's Disease is a type of squamous cell carcinoma in situ that presents as an erythematous scaly plaque.

Option C: Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disorder presenting with erythematous plaques with silver coloured scales.

Note: Follicular mucinosis is the only other cutaneous T-cell lymphoma given in the options.

questions.text: The image depicts a technique used to visualise corneal topographic lesions. The technique is:
questions.solution:
Fluorescein Staining is the technique shown in the image.

Corneal Epithelial Lesions are visualised using vital dye staining techniques.
Dyes used are:

  1. Fluorescein - to delineate areas with epithelial damage
  2. Rose Bengal - Stain Diseased and devitalised cells

      3. Alcian Blue - Stains excess mucus selectively


Indocyanin Green is only used in Angiography of Choroidal Vasculature.

questions.text: Penicillin is most likely to kill the bacteria in which phase of the bacterial growth curve shown below?
questions.solution:
The log (logarithmic) phase, also known as the exponential phase is when rapid cell division occurs. β -Lactam drugs, such as penicillin, act during this phase because the drugs are effective when cells are making peptidoglycan (i.e., when they are dividing).

The first is the lag phase, during which vigorous metabolic activity occurs but cells do not divide. This can last for a few minutes up to many hours.
The stationary phase occurs when nutrient depletion or toxic products cause growth to slow until the number of new cells produced balances the number of cells that die, resulting in a steady-state.
The final phase is the death phase, which is marked by a decline in the number of viable bacteria.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child developed sore throat and difficulty in swallowing and mild fever. On examination, the clinical picture shown below is seen. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: Its administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh
A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication
Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.solution:
The image shows a dirty white pseudomembrane classic of diphtheria. A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 37 is not a contraindication. 

Precautionary measures are taken when the temperature is above 40 degrees, but it is not considered a contraindication for subsequent doses of DPwT.

Anaphylaxis is a contraindication for subsequent vaccination with diphtheria, pertussis, or tetanus vaccine. Encephalopathy following vaccination is a contraindication for pertussis vaccine. DT is given for successive doses.

Events such as inconsolable cry, fever more than 40.5°C, seizures with or without fever are considered as precautions, and not contraindications for DTwP.

The cellular component of pertussis is not recommended after 7 years.

  • Unvaccinated child 5-7 years: Give DPT 1, 2 and 3 at 1-month intervals. Administer booster dose of DPT at a minimum of 6 months
    after administering DPT-3 up to the age of 7 years.
  • Unvaccinated child above 7 years: Administer Tdap (Tetanus and diphtheria toxoids and acellular pertussis) at 0, and Td (Tetanus, Diphtheria vaccine) at 1 and 6 months, respectively.

The adult dose of diphtheria toxoid is almost 12 times lesser in comparison with the pediatric dosage.

Note: IAP guidelines state that "temperature more than >40.5°C is a precaution and not contraindication". Park's 27th Ed states that "temperature above 40°C is a contraindication to DPT". This topic is controversial, however, IAP guidelines are commonly followed by practitioners.

questions.text: The bond shown in the image is?
questions.solution:
The image shows an Isopeptide Bond.

Isopeptide bond is an amide bond between the carboxyl group of one amino acid and the amino group of another.

At least one of these joining groups is part of the side chain of one of these amino acids.

It is distinct from the eupeptide(peptide) bond which forms between c1 carbon of one amino acid to N2 nitrogen of another amino acid in a Peptide chain.

questions.text: The number of stereoisomers of the given compound is
questions.solution:
The given image shows the chemical structure of glucose with 4 Asymmetric carbon atoms.

Using Van't Hoff rule, the number stereoisomers is 2 to the Power n where n is the number of asymmetric carbon atoms. As there are 4 asymmetric carbons here, 16 stereoisomers.

Two enantiomers each of eight different diastereomers: allose, altrose, glucose, mannose, gulose, idose, galactose, and talose.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient was referred for evaluation of a progressive left-hand weakness and pain involving his right medial elbow, forearm, wrist and thumb. Suspecting pure neuritic leprosy, a nerve biopsy was taken and the image of the histological section is given below. What is the stain used in this section?
questions.solution:
The stain used in this section is osmium tetroxide. 

Osmium tetroxide is reduced to a black substance by unsaturated fatty acids present in the myelin sheath of the nerve fibers and hence, appears black on the section.

The pure neuritic form is a variant of leprosy characterized by the isolated involvement of peripheral nerve trunks with the absence of skin lesions. Nerve biopsy is the gold standard method for the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the government program depicted in the image given below?

choices.text: Health Insurance cover of  5 lakh rupees per family, per year
Only the poor and vulnerable families are benefited under this program
The program was launched on 15th August 2018
Provides cashless and paperless  access to quality health care services

questions.solution:
The Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana was announced on the 15th of August 2018 but it was launched on 23rd September 2018.

PM JAY

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • More than 10.74 crore poor and vulnerable families (approximately 50 crore beneficiaries) covered across the country.
  • All families listed in the SECC database as per defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to the girl child, women and senior citizens.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.

questions.text: The image shows a boy with a deformity of left upper limb. Select the incorrect statement regarding the complications of this condition:

choices.text: Tardy Ulnar Nerve Palsy is an early complication

questions.solution:
This image shows a Cubitus Valgus, which is a complication of non-union or malunion of a lateral condyle fracture.

Tardy Ulnar Nerve Palsy is a Late, not early, complication of Lateral condyle fracture of humerus.

Complications of Lateral Condyle Humerus Fractures:

  • Most Common - Non-Union
  • Malunion -> Lateral Spur Formation -> Tardy Ulnar Nerve Palsy (Late complication)
  • Growth Arrest
  • Avascular Necrosis
  • Fishtail Deformity

questions.text: A patient with bronchogenic carcinoma presents to your OPD complaining of hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy,  you ask him to phonate and notice that the left vocal cord does not abduct. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is of unilateral vocal cord palsy secondary to bronchogenic carcinoma. The posterior cricoarytenoids are involved here (marked as 3), as they are paralyzed since the tumor invades unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Other structures:

1. Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle - closes the ligamentous part of rima glottidis

2. Transverse arytenoid muscle - closes the inter cartilaginous part of the rima glottidis

4. Cricothyroid muscle - it is a tensor of the vocal cord.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive ataxia and symptoms of increased intracranial tension, including headaches and vomiting. MR spectroscopy is performed, as shown below. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak is diagnostic of glioma. Creatinine levels are decreased on MR spectroscopy in patients with glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information. The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma shows a lipid peak in MR spectroscopy.  

Option C: In Canavan disease, there is a marked increase in N-acetyl aspartate. Its concentration decreases with insults to the brain such as neoplasm, infarct, or abscess. N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) which is the most prominent resonance in a proton spectrum, is accepted as a normal neuronal functional marker.

Option D: Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in lymphoma. However, lymphomas of the nervous system are very rare and seen in immunodeficient states like HIV.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
The patient has an organized, apparently normal ECG without a pulse - i.e the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). A pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

The immediate treatment for this is giving chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest until definitive therapy to the cause can be instituted.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: Reversible Causes of Cardiac Arrest

  • 5 H’s:
    • Hypovolemia
    • Hypoxia
    • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
    • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
    • Hypothermia
  • 5 T’s:
    • Tension pneumothorax
    • Tamponade (cardiac)
    • Toxins
    • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
    • Thrombosis (coronary)

questions.text: Identify the device shown below:
questions.solution:
The image shown above is of Lack's circuit, which is a co-axial modification of Mapleson's A circuit.

Co-axial circuits have two tubings, one inner and one outer tubing (arranged co-axially).

Lack's circuit has:

  • Inner expiratory tubing: carries exhaust gases out through APL valve
  • Outer inspiratory tubing: carries fresh gas flow to the patient

Magill's circuit (Mapleson A) designed by Sir Ivan Magill, best suited for spontaneous ventilation.

Jackson and Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is a modification of Ayre's T piece. Best suited for children under 20 kg.

questions.text: The method shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The image shows Marshall Burns's technique used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Baby is allowed to hang by its weight till the nape of the neck is visible
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, the baby is grasped by the ankles
  • Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction towards the mother's abdomen

Other Options: 

Option A: Pinard’s manoeuvre used for delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Option B: The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique is another method that can be used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Option D: The Ritgen manoeuvre is used for controlled delivery of the head in normal labour.

questions.text: The device shown in the image is
questions.solution:
The image shows Trocar and port used in Laparoscopic surgery.
Commonly associated complications:

  • Vascular injury - especially of distal aorta and right common iliac.
  • Bowel Injury - Many bowel injuries present postoperatively often with peritonitis.

questions.text: The image shows:
questions.solution:
The image in question shows Fuller’s Bivalved Metallic tracheostomy tube.

Characteristics:

  • Made of metal
  • Bivalved - Split outer tube that also functions as an introducer
  • Inner-tube has slit on top
  • Phonation is possible
  • Inner tube extends beyond the outer tube (facilitates cleaning)

The image below shows a Tracheostomy tube with inflatable cuff.

This permits positive pressure ventilation to be done.

Image below shows a Chevalier - Jackson’s Silver Tracheostomy tube - Curved tube.

Named so because the inner tube is made of silver.

Needs an introducer.

Cannot be used in radiotherapy patients as it causes scatter of radiation resulting in nearby tissue damage.

questions.text: The abnormality noted in the given image of placenta is

choices.text: The cord is attached to the membranes
Fetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery
A small lobe of placenta lies seperate from main part

questions.solution:
The image depicts the battledore placenta in which the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.

In the Battledore placenta, the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a Previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

Other options:

Option A: Velamentous placenta - the cord is attached to the membranes and blood vessels pass through the membrane and then the placenta to supply it.

Option B: Circumvallate placenta - the fetal surface of the placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery which is made of a double fold of amnion and chorion.

Option D: Succenturiate placenta - one or small lobes of the placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: In a plain X-ray of the abdomen, the small bowel is said to be dilated if the diameter is more than  ______.
questions.solution:
The small bowel is said to be dilated if the diameter is more than 3 cm in a plain X-ray.

The following triad of findings is specific for small bowel obstruction on plain X-ray imaging of the abdomen:

  • Dilated small bowel loops (>3 cm in diameter)
  • Air-fluid levels seen on upright films 
  • A paucity of air in the colon.

questions.text: A victim was recovered from the site of a terrorist attack. Which of the following conclusions can be made from the image shown below of the victim?

choices.text: The victim has been shot at with a shotgun from close range.
The victim has been hit by multiple shrapnel, possibly from an explosion.
The victim has had multiple cut wounds all over the body.
The victim has had multiple stab wounds all over the body.

questions.solution:
From the image shown, it can be inferred that the victim has been hit by multiple shrapnel, possibly from an explosion. Shrapnel wounds are also called secondary blast injuries. 

Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma, resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion that causes a sudden increase or decrease in atmospheric pressure.

TK Marshall (Marshall's triad) described the characteristic injuries associated with bomb explosions:

  • Abrasions
  • Bruises/contusions
  • Puncture lacerations
Blast injuries are classified as follows:
  • Primary injuries: These are caused by the effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures and are characterized by only internal injuries. 
  • Secondary injuries: These are injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.
  • Tertiary injuries: These are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.
  • Quaternary injuries: All other injuries caused by explosions that are not included in the above three categories, e.g. flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, and gas

Other options:

The highly spread-out nature of the wounds effectively rules out close-range shotgun injury. Also, the pattern of the wounds is not consistent with cuts or stabs.

 

Related Pearl: Types of Blast Injuries

Blast injury type

Mechanism of injury

Health impact

Primary

Rapid crushing over pressure

Tympanic membrane (most common), Lung (2nd most common), eyes, GIT

Secondary

Flying debris

MARSHAL’s triad (triad of abrasions, contuisions, lacerations)

Tertiary

Blast wind

Victim is thrown in air and strikes other objects leading to fracture and blunt trauma

Quaternary

Any complicating factor not in the other three categories

Burns, histotoxicanoxia, and crush injuries
  • The specific pulmonary injury of air blast is known as blast lung.
  • When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.
  • Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.
  • Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text: The given image shows fragments of DNA after electrophoresis. The relationship between the sizes of the different fragments is

choices.text: Length relationship cannot be predicted from this
It depends on the species whose DNA is being analysed.

questions.solution:
The smaller the fragment size, the farther it travels. Hence correct length relationship is A>B>C>D


From the Marker Column, the fragment marked A is the closest from the main sample, while the fragment B, C & D are positioned progressively farther away from each other. As we know, the smaller the size of the fragment, the farther it travels (From top to bottom in this image). Hence. A>B>C>D

questions.text: As an intern posted in the Labour Ward, you observe a newborn with typical Potter facies as shown below. Which of the following associations would you not expect in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic features consistent with potter Syndrome facies. It has male, not female predominance.

Features of Potter Syndrome are:

  • Bilateral Renal Agenesis leads to oligohydramnios, in turn causing pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Resultant characteristic Potter Facies -
    • Widely separated eyes with epicanthic fold
    • Small, low-set ears
    • Flat & broad nose
    • Receding Chin
  • Limb Anomalies
  • Wrinkled Skin

Interestingly, the cause of death is pulmonary insufficiency from pulmonary hypoplasia, not renal failure.

questions.text: The most commonly fractured bone among the carpal Bones is:
questions.solution:
The most commonly fractured bone is Scaphoid which is denoted by 1 in the image.

Relative incidence of carpal Bone Fracture - Scaphoid > Triquetrum > Trapezium.

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics depicted in the Graph is suggestive of-
questions.solution:
The graph shows a hyperbola which is suggestive of Michaelis - Menten Kinetics of the enzyme.

For enzymes showing michaelis menten kinetics, there is an increase in Rate of reaction, V, with increase in substrate concentration till a point Vmax is reached beyond which rate of reaction shows saturation.

Cooperative Binding would result in a sigmoid curve and is suggestive of Non Michaelis Menten Kinetics.

questions.text: The energetically allowed angle phi and psi are given by
questions.solution:
The energetically allowed phi and psi angles in the amino acids are given by the Ramachandran Plot.
Watson and Crick proposed the double helical model for structure of DNA. Rosalind Franklin was an X Ray crystallographer who also contributed to deciphering the structure of DNA.

questions.solution:

questions.text: What type of antagonism is shown by drugs A and B in the following dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
The parallel rightward shift of the agonist dose-response curve (DRC) is seen with competitive antagonism.

Increasing the dose of the agonist can result in the same maximal response.

In non-competitive antagonism, there will be flattening of the agonist DRC.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman underwent a trucut biopsy for the suspicion of malignancy on a mammogram. Microscopy showed the presence of invasive breast carcinoma. IHC staining of the tumor is given below. Which of the following drugs will you add along with chemotherapeutic agents for treating this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. Chemotherapy along with endocrine therapy, and trastuzumab is the adjuvant treatment of choice.

Positive immunohistochemistry staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  • Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given for patients with tumors that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).
  • Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given for patients with tumors that are HER2 overexpressing.
  • Chemotherapy is given for hormone negative, HER2+, and ER+ tumors.

The table below shows the summary of the adjuvant treatment approach:

  Tumor hormone receptor status (ER,PR)
Tumor HER2/neu status Positive Negative  
Positive Endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab Chemotherapy + trastuzumab
Negative Endocrine therapy ± chemotherapy Chemotherapy

Note: Palbociclib is used along with hormone therapy in ER +ve, PR +ve, HER2/neu -ve tumors.

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a laryngeal mirror which is identified by its straight shaft without any bends with a mirror at the end.

Indirect Laryngoscopy is done by the use of a laryngeal mirror.

The patient is seated straight opposite the examiner, with the head and chest leaning slightly towards him. He is asked to protrude his tongue which is wrapped in gauze for protection from any inadvertent injury. The tongue is held by the examiner between the thumb and middle finger.

The laryngeal mirror (size 4–6) is introduced into the mouth and held firmly against the uvula and soft palate. It should be warmed and tested on the back of the hand before introduction. Light is focused on the laryngeal mirror and the patient is asked to breathe quietly. Movements of both cords are seen and compared by asking the patient to take deep inspiration (abduction of cords), say “Aa” (adduction of cords), and “Eee” (for adduction and tension).

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy (in order) are:

  • The base of the tongue (posterior one-third of the tongue)
  • Vallecula
  • Median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds
  • Epiglottis
  • Pharyngoepiglottic folds
  • Aryepiglottic folds
  • Arytenoids
  • False vocal cords
  • True vocal cords

Other options:

Options A and C: St. Clair Thompson mirror is the other name for the Postnasal/ posterior rhinoscopy mirror. It has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

Option D: A double hook retractor is used to retract soft tissues during surgery.

questions.text: The false statement regarding the method shown in the image is

choices.text: Can be continued in babies >2500 g also

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo mother care. It is for discontinued for babies above 2500 grams.
Principles of Kangaroo Mother Care

  • SSC - Skin to Skin contact
  • Exclusive Breastfeeding
  • Early home  discharge and followup.


KMC can even be done on mothers that are on IV fluids, CPAP or even ventilators if they are hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: Identify the type of muscle tissue shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a longitudinal section of the cardiac muscle stained by hematoxylin and eosin.

On microscopy, cardiac muscle can be identified by:

  • Presence of striations similar to the skeletal muscle.
  • Presence of single and centrally placed nucleus. A perinuclear halo may be seen surrounding the nucleus.
  • The junctions between adjoining cardiac myocytes are seen as dark staining transverse lines running across the muscle fibre. These lines are called intercalated discs.
  • Cells within one fibre branch and join the cells in adjacent fibres.
