questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the arthropod in the image given below?

choices.text: The female fly does not lay eggs.
The life span is less than 100 days.
Sterile female release technique is followed for control.

questions.solution:
The image shows Tsetse fly which is the causative agent of trypanosomiasis or “Sleeping sickness”

Sterile male, not female, release technique is followed for the control of the fly.

DDT 25% and Dieldrin 18-20% are the insecticides used commonly for the control of tsetse fly.

The female does not lay eggs. It gives birth to the larva.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is the cause for the effect shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Osteonecrosis of jaw, which is a side effect of the Bisphosphonates like Zoledronate.

Side effects of Zoledronate:

  • Nausea, vomiting, bodyache
  • Renal toxicity
  • Osteonecrosis of jaw
  • Hypocalcaemia and seizures
  • Increased risk of bone fractures
  • Bone pain

questions.text: Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
The image shows Pilon fracture, a distal tibia fracture.

The other name for Pilon fracture is Plafond fracture.

Mechanism of Injury: Axial Loading of the tibia.

Distal Tibia Fractures are more prone to go for nonunion because of relative avascularity.

The injury is better assessed with CT than with X Rays.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is ansa cervicalis and thyrohyoid is not supplied by it. Thyrohyoid is supplied by the C1 fibers through the hypoglossal nerve.

The muscles supplied by ansa cervicalis are:

  • Sternothyroid
  • Sternohyoid
  • Omohyoid both inferior and superior belly

The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop embedded in the anterior wall of the carotid sheath. It is formed by two roots:

  • The superior root is a continuation of the descending branch of the hypoglossal nerve. It is derived from the 1st cervical nerve (C1) and supplies the superior belly of the omohyoid.
  • The inferior root is derived from the 2nd and 3rd cervical spinal nerves (C2, C3).

questions.text: Identify the structures marked as 1 to 4, respectively, in the chorionic plate of the placental tissue as depicted below.
questions.solution: The structures labeled in the above image of the chorionic plate (fetal component) are (1) amnion, (2) extraembryonic mesoderm, (3) cytotrophoblast, and (4) syncytiotrophoblast.

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman was rushed to the ICU following an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There was no history of fever, night sweats or weight loss. MRI scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. MRI scan shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

It usually has multiple lesions in multiple locations which are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring; this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is also present.

Treatment includes sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Primary prophylaxis: It is given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given.

Secondary prophyaxis/maintanace therapy: It is given when CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL. Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given. It is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are maintained >200/μL for 6 months.

Option A: Cryptococcal meningitis presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. Seizures and focal neurologic deficits are rarely seen. MRI findings include dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts. 

Option B: Primary CNS lymphoma also presents with seizures and focal neurological deficit. Symptoms of fever, night sweats and weight loss are present in 80% of the patients. On imaging, it is identified as a CT hyperdense enhancing supratentorial mass, with MRI T1 hypointense, T2 iso- to hypointense, vivid homogeneous enhancement as well as restricted diffusion. 

Option C: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, caused by JC virus, is characterized by demyelination in subcortical white matter reflected on MRI as multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

Type of ALL  Immunophenotype 
Early Pre-B ALL  TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 
Pre B ALL  TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig

questions.text: Identify the cell in the given peripheral blood smear and the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease

questions.solution:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.

Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye.

Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes.

Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include:

  • Anaemia of renal disease (uremia)
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artefact

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

questions.text: You notice that on turning the baby’s head to one side, a reflex response as shown in the image is elicited. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this response?

choices.text: The reflex is useful in early hand regard by the baby
It is elicited in supine position

questions.solution:
The image shows Asymmetric Tonic Neck Reflex(ATNR).  ATNR appears by 35wk gestation, fully develops by 1 month postnatally and disappears by 6 to 7months.

The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm).

The extended arm aids better hand regard by the baby.

The tonic neck reflexes are brainstem reflexes.

questions.text:
Match the marked structures to the correct layers of the cerebellar cortex.
A 1. White matter
B 2. Molecular layer
C 3. Purkinje layer
D 4. Granular layer
questions.solution:
The structures marked in the given image are:

A - Molecular layer

B - Purkinje layer

C - Granular layer

D - White matter

The cerebellum is covered by pia mater which is seen as thin connective tissue, with blood vessels lying under it. The cerebellum consists of an outer grey matter (cerebellar cortex) and inner white matter.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: The following X-Ray in a patient with a tear of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a Maisonneuve Fracture.

Maissonneuve Fracture is a spiral fracture of proximal fibula and ankle ligament injury.

It usually occurs in cases of direct trauma or indirect twisting injury of the lower limb.

The fracture is often associated with other major injuries of lower limb.

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image represents "miliary tuberculosis". Individual lesions are small (2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma 

Miliary tuberculosis (TB) is the widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis via hematogenous spread. It occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. Miliary TB may infect any number of organs, including the lungs, liver and spleen.

The adjective “miliary” is derived from the resemblance of these foci to millet seeds. Montaux test is negative in miliary TB.

questions.text: Given is an image of hematoxylin and eosin stained of infected tissue. Which of the following is not true regarding the organism seen?

choices.text: Allergy following inhalation of airborne particles of the fungus
Colonization of tuberculous cavities in the lung
They proliferate in the walls of blood vessels cause infarction and necrosis of tissue.

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Aspergillus fumigatus.

It shows the characteristic feature of septate hyphae that branch at an acute angle of ~45 degrees.
This fungus causes

  • Invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients
  • Aspergillomas in pre-existing lung cavities
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis

Mucor, not Aspergillus, proliferate in blood vessel wall. 

Mucor fungi

They have irregular, broad, non-septate hyphae branching at wide angles.

They cause diseases mostly in ketoacidotic diabetic and/or neutropenic patients.  

Fungi proliferate in blood vessel walls, penetrate cribriform plate, and enter the brain.

They can cause rhinocerebral, frontal lobe abscess, and cavernous sinus thrombosis, which can manifest as headache; facial pain; black necrotic eschar on face; and, sometimes, cranial nerve involvement.

questions.text: Currently the most common indication for the placement of the device shown in image is:

choices.text: Foreign Body Obstruction of upper airway

questions.solution:
The image shows a cuffed tracheostomy tube.

In modern times, the most common indication for tracheostomy is need for prolonged ventilatory support.

The cuffed tracheostomy tube permits positive pressure ventilation to be administered. Laryngomalacia often takes a benign course and spontaneously resolves. Certainly not a common indication for tracheostomy.

Foreign body obstruction of upper airway and subglottic hemangiomas less frequently require tracheostomy with advent of other treatment modalities.

questions.text: The surgical treatment option with the best outcomes for the urological condition depicted in the image is:

choices.text: Nephrectomy of the damaged kidney to prevent recurrent UTI

questions.solution:
The image shows a grade-V vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). The surgical treatment for this is ureteric reimplantation. Here, the ureter is reimplanted in a different site in the bladder from the normal anatomic site.

VUR refers to an abnormal flow of urine from the bladder to the ureters. This reflux predisposes to pyelonephritis by allowing the entry of bacteria into the usually sterile upper tract.

The diagnosis is first suspected after a UTI in a very young child or recurrent UTIs. USG may reveal abnormalities like hydronephrosis and dilated ureters. VCUG/MCU must be performed in such children before the age of 6 years to look for:

  • Presence and grade of VUR
  • Whether reflux occurs during micturition or during bladder filling
  • Presence of associated anatomical anomalies

As VUR is autosomal dominant, USG screening is done in other siblings to rule out the disease. However,  MCU (micturating cystourethrogram) remains the investigation of choice. 

Scars can be ruled out using DMSA renal scintigraphy. VUR is the most common cause of renal scarring and hence scarring is considered one of the indicators of VUR.

The grading of VUR is based on the height of reflux up the ureters and the degree of dilatation of the ureters.

The other surgical modalities mentioned in the options have no role in isolated vesicoureteric reflux.

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to test __________
questions.solution:
The device shows synoptophore which is used to test binocular single vision.

The synoptophore compensates for the angle of squint and allows stimuli to be presented to both eyes simultaneously. It can thus be used to investigate the potential for binocular function in the presence of a manifest squint. It is of particular value in assessing young children (from age 3 years), who generally find the test process enjoyable.

Purtscher retinopathy may follow severe trauma and involves occlusion and ischemia associated with microvascular damage in the retina. Patient presents with sudden bilateral reduction of vision and purtscher flecken (Multiple or bilateral superficial white retinal patches.)

Related Pearl: Grades of binocular vision

I - Simultaneous perception                       

  • Ability to see two dissimilar objects simultaneously

II - Fusion

  • Ability to superimpose two incomplete but similar images

III - Stereopsis

  • Ability to perceive depth

questions.text: The wrong statement about the given image is :

choices.text: At point A vertical rays are converging more rapidly than horizontal rays.
At point B - Vertical rays have come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging, so it will be a horizontal straight line
At point C the horizontal rays are diverging and vertical rays are converging
Point D is the circle of least confusion.

questions.solution:
The given image shows a sturm’s conoid.

The vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging at point C.

  • Horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays are converging more rapidly than horizontal at point A.
  • Vertical rays have come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging, so it will be a horizontal straight line at point B
  • Vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging at points C, D and E.
  • Vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged at point D, so we get a perfect circle called circle of least confusion. At this point, the divergence of vertical rays is exactly equal to the convergence of the horizontal rays from the axis.
  • At point E - Vertical oval
  • At point F - vertical straight line
  • At point G and beyond - Both rays are diverging and we always get a vertical oval / prolate ellipse.

questions.text: Jersey finger is due to injury of _______

choices.text: Extensor tendon over the DIP joint

questions.solution:
The Jersey finger is caused by the rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus from the distal phalanx.

It occurs when there is hyperextension of the flexed finger trapped in a jersey. On physical examination, the finger lies in slight extension relative to other fingers in the resting position and no active flexion of DIP is possible.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: What is the frequency at which the post-placement medical examination should be done in an individual whose occupational exposure is related to the symbol shown below?
questions.solution:
The symbol signifies radiation hazard, the post-placement medical examination in radiation industry workers is done at a frequency of once in 2 months or 6 times a year.

  • Daily examination is done for Dichromate exposure
  • Monthly for lead, dye exposure
  • Annual medical examination is done for most other occupational exposures.

questions.text: All are true about the images shown below except:

choices.text: Compression of the central arteriole with a pinhead results in blanching followed by reformation
Seen along the superior  venacava (SVC)  territory
Due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen by the cirrhotic liver

questions.solution:
More than 2 to 3 spider telangiectasias are considered abnormal.

Spider telengectasia (Naevus)

  • Spider naevus consist of a centrel arteriole(millimeters to 2cm) about pin headed size from which steadily narrowing capillaries radiate like spider legs.
  • Compression of the central arteriole with a pinhead results in blanching followed by reformation of the “spider” after release of pressure on the arteriole
  • More than 2 to 3 spider telangiectasias are considered abnormal
  • Seen along the superior venacava (SVC) territory(reason unknown).
  • Spider naveus is also  seen in pregnancy,rheumatoid arthritis,use of estrogen containing pills.
  • It results due to hyperestronemic state

Other clinical findings seen in cirrhosis 

Parotid enlargement 

Parotid enlargement is occasionally found in cirrhotic patient especially in alcoholic Cirhosis. Enlarged parotid are painless.

Palmar erythema:

Palmar erythema are  symmetrical, both hands, non-painful, Non-itchy, slightly warm (vasodialation). Vasodialation is due to increased estogen level in blood. Center of the palm is usually spared.

Palmar erethema is also seen in hyperthyroidism, pregnancy, collagen vascular diseases.

Caput medusae:

Dilated abdominal veins with flow away from the umbilicus, toward the inferior vena cava in the infraumbilical area and toward the superior vena cava in the supraumbilical area, suggest intrahepatic portal hypertension.

White nail & paper money skin:

Paper money skin of the chronic liver patient often resembles so-called parchment skin. it appears prematurely aged. shrivelled, wrinkled, dry and atrophic — mostly greyish yellow in colour.

Other findings are

  • Testicular atrophy(<4ml)
  • Gynacomastia

questions.text: The device shown in the image works upon the principle of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows radiant warmers. They work under the principle of radiant heating.

Incubators work under the principle of Convective Heating.

The device is set in servo control mode and the temperature is set at 36.5 to 37-degree celsius.

 

Ideal Temperature of:

  • NICU - 30+/- 2 Degree celsius.
  • Labour Room - 25 Degree celsius

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein deposition.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.

questions.text: Which drug can be used for pain relief in a patient with the following barium swallow?
questions.solution:
Sildenafil citrate - PDE 5 inhibitor can be used for pain relief in diffuse esophageal spasm.

The image depicts Corkscrew / Rosary bead appearance of the esophagus, characteristically seen in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm.

The pathophysiology of the disease, at least in part, involves inadequate Nitric Oxide(NO) synthesis or impaired Degradation of NO.

Treatment:

Initial Therapy: Calcium Channel Blocker - CCB (Diltiazem)

Tri-Cyclic Antidepressants - TCA (Imipramine)

For resistant Cases:NO Donors (Sildenafil/Nitrates)

Botulinum Toxin.

questions.text: The condition shown below results from an  Aedes aegypti transmitted flaviviral infection during pregnancy. Identify the virus implicated.
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an infected pregnant mother to her child. Zika virus is a mosquito borne flavivirus mainly transmitted through Aedes aegypti. The symptoms of the infection are similar to dengue and include fever, skin rashes, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain.

NCDC Delhi and National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does this capnographic waveform appear?
questions.solution:
The image given in the question shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by absence of carbon dioxide- this is typical of esophageal intubation.

Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero.

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia – progressive rise in CO2. 

Option C: Rebreathing of CO2 - elevated inspiratory baseline.

Option D: Tracheal intubation - normal capnograph.

questions.text: The type of knot seen in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the suture material exiting the knot is on the same side as the entry i.e no cross-over is seen. This is seen in a reef knot.

A knot is a fastening made of threads intertwined together or on themselves. Each knot consists of- 2 half-hitches placed in sequential throws. Squaring refers to tightening the knot/half-hitch in a manner that the threads lay flat due to the alternating direction of half-hitches in adjacent layers.

Types of knots:

  1. Granny knot: half-hitch over a half-hitch in the same direction. It has better-holding power than half-hitch
  2. Reef knot: half-hitch followed by a second half-hitch after squaring. 
  3. Triple throw knot: Reef knot with another half-hitch knot for added security. Knots made with prolene sutures require 6-8 throws to prevent slippage.
  4. Surgeon’s knot: Modification of the reef knot with two half-hitches in the first layer.
  5. Slip knot: Modification of either granny/reef knot formed when one end of the thread is kept taut while tightening the knot.

questions.text: What is the case fatality rate for the disease caused by the virus shown below that spreads through the vector shown below?
questions.solution:
Nipah virus, Transmitted by Bats has a case fatality rate of 75%.
This is a colorized transmission electron micrograph of mature extracellular Nipah virus particles (blue) near infected vero cell (purple). The average case fatality rate of Nipah virus infection is 75%.

This is an RNA virus grouped under the genus henipavirus in the family paramyxoviridae. The primary animal reservoirs are the bats belonging to the genus (pteropus).

The viral infection usually results in viral encephalitis, Recently there was an outbreak of this condition in Kerala in May 2018.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with 3 months history of breathlessness. After Evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with mitral stenosis. Which of the following is least likely to be heard on auscultation?
questions.solution:
Mid-systolic click is least likely to be heard in a patient with mitral stenosis. It is seen in a patient with mitral valve prolapse.

Important clinical features of Mitral stenosis
Findings Cause
Inspection
Malar flush, pinched and blue facies Decreased cardiac output and increased pulmonary artery hypertension leads to retention of CO2 and vasodilation
Precordial bulge  
Palpation
Parasternal lift Enlarged right ventricle
Palpable P2 Pulmonary hypertension
Diastolic thrill Increased intensity of diastolic murmur
Auscultation
Loud S1 It is seen in initial stages when the mitral valve is flexible.
Opening snap (OS)

It is caused due to the sudden opening of thickened leaflets.

It follows A2. As the disease progresses, the duration between A2 and OS decreases.

It is best audible at the apex and with the diaphragm of the stethoscope
Diastolic murmur

Low pitched rumbling murmur heard with the bell of the stethoscope.

It follows OS and best heard at apex with left lateral recumbent position. When it is loud, may radiate to left axilla. 

The duration of murmur correlates with the severity of stenosis
Loud P2 Pulmonary artery hypertension
Other Auscultatory Findings
Pansystolic murmur Due to functional tricuspid regurgitation in severe pulmonary hypertension
Graham Steell murmur

It is a diastolic murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation

Caused due to the dilation of the pulmonary valve ring in severe pulmonary hypertension
JVP

ECG

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).

The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

VEXAS syndrome (vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, autoinflammatory, somatic) is a Novel disorder discovered in 2020. It is an adult-onset inflammatory disease with clinical features that bridge rheumatologic & hematologic conditions. VEXAS may be a prototype for new class of “hematoinflammatory diseases.” These diseases would be defined by somatic mutations in hematopoietic cells, systemic inflammation, & potential to evolve into overt myelodysplastic, myeloproliferative, or lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presents to the clinic with the following skin lesion. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
This "classic" bull's-eye rash is also called erythema migrans. This lesion is usually seen in individuals with Lyme’s disease.
In children with Lyme disease amoxicillin is the drug of choice.

Doxycycline is generally the drug of choice in Lyme’s disease except in pregnant, lactating women and children under 8 where amoxicillin is used.
Doxycycline is preferred because it has excellent CNS penetration and it can be used to treat anaplasmosis which can coexist with the Lyme’s disease.

Ceftriaxone is reserved for patients with late neurological findings.
Although Azithromycin can be used for treatment treating with amoxicillin gave superior results and shorter treatment time.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used for the detection of variations in DNA sequences and gene expression?
questions.solution:
DNA microarray can be used to detect DNA sequence variations.

There are various microarray techniques used in clinical practice which are described below:

DNA Microarray technique or DNA chip:

  • To the DNA chip containing known oligonucleotide sequence, flourescent labelled unknown oligonucleotide is added.
  • The computerised algorithms can decode the unknown oligonucleotide, by detecting the location of flourescent hybridization pattern on the chip.
  • This technique is used for genotyping or genome sequencing.

RNA microarray: RNA microarray can detect gene expression.

  • To the known array of oligonucleotide, flourecently labelled cDNA prepared from unknown mRNA is added, and the unknown cDNA is decoded
  • This technique is used for gene expression studies

Protein microarray:

  • Known antibodies placed on glass slide and flourescently tagged target protein added. Target protein is detected by antigen antibody interaction.
  • This technique is used in study of proteomics

questions.text: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures. 

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acute anal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

Proctoscopy is indicated in patients with the following:

  • Rectal bleeding
  • Change in bowel habit, especially recurring attacks of diarrhea
  • Pain or difficulty in defecation
  • Lesions around the anal opening - abscesses, fistulae, discharge, ulcers, external hemorrhoids
  • Rectal prolapse.

questions.text: The image shows a young child with characteristic old age appearance. The syndromes that show similar acceleration of physiological events associated with aging are
questions.solution:
The image shows a child with Hutchinson-Gilford Syndrome.
The three genetic diseases associated with acceleration of physiological events associated with aging are

  • Down’s Syndrome
  • Hutchinson Gilford Syndrome
  • Werner Syndrome


Werner Syndrome is due to defective Homologous repair of DNA damage.Premature aging begins in adolescence and results in Old age appearance by the age of 30-40. It shows autosomal recessive inheritance - WRN Gene, Chromosome 8.

Physical characteristics:

  • Wrinkled skin
  • Baldness
  • Cataracts
  • Muscular atrophy
  • Increased risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus.


Hutchinson Gilford Syndrome

Characteristic Dramatic rapid appearance of aging beginning in childhood. Characteristic facial appearance including prominent eyes, a thin nose with a beaked tip, thin lips, a small chin, and protruding ears.

Progeria encompases diseases characterised by premature aging symptoms. However, it often specifically refres to Hutchinson-Gilford syndrome. It was first described by Jonathan Hutchinson and Hastings Gilford separately. It is believed that F. Scott Fitzgerald's main character in his book "The curious case of Benjamin Button" was inspired by progeria. The bollywood movie Paa was also potrayed a 12 year old boy suffering from Progeria.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the graph shown below?

choices.text: This is an example of a negative skew.

questions.solution:
The graph does not show a normal distribution. The image shows a negatively skewed distribution.

A normal distribution has the data distributed symmetrically. This data distribution is asymmetric. 

A distribution is negatively skewed, or skewed to the left, if the scores fall toward the higher side of the scale and there are very few low scores.

Here Mode>Median>Mean whereas in Right skewed distribution Mean>Median>Mode

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Which mode does the following waveform of cautery represent?
questions.solution:
Cutting is a mode of diathermy/electrosurgery. The cut current is a low voltage, continuous waveform. Cutting occurs when sufficient heat is applied to the tissue to cause cell water to explode into steam.

Coagulation is the sealing of blood vessels. In coagulation, a heating effect leads to cell death by dehydration and protein denaturation.

Blend is the combination of cutting and coagulation.

Fulguration refers to destructive coagulation of tissues with charring. The diathermy matching is set to coagulation and a higher effective voltage is used to make larger sparks jump an air gap thus fulgurating the tissues.

questions.text: The sign shown in the image below is seen in paralysis of ______
questions.solution:
The above image shows positive trendelenburg’s sign, which is seen in paralysis of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. These patients also have a characteristic lurching gait.

Mechanism of actions of Gluteus medius and minimus: 

  • When leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.

questions.text: Which of the following represents a holocrine gland?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image marked ‘B’ represents the sebaceous gland, which is a type of holocrine gland.

Holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen.

Examples of holocrine glands are

  • Sebaceous glands of the skin and
  • Meibomian glands of the eyelid

Image A: Sweat glands - Eccrine/merocrine glands; glands remain intact

Image C: Mammary gland - Apocrine gland; apical part sheds to secrete

Image D: Ceruminous gland - Apocrine glands

questions.text: Given below is an instrument which is used to measure air humidity. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is a Sling Psychrometer, It is used to measure the humidity/ moisture content in the air.

Sling Psychrometer has a 2 mercury thermometers (wet and dry) in it. The wet bulb is moistened first with distilled water and the instrument is whirled / rotated standing with the back to the sun. The reading is noted twice.

Later the dry bulb is taken up for the reading and the relative air humidity is obtained by use of suitable tables and charts.

 

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the casualty with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate is 170/min and his blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg. His ECG is given below. What is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
This patient has supraventricular tachycardia with evidence of hemodynamic deterioration. Immediate treatment would be cardioversion (50-100J).

If the patient were hemodyamically stable, initial treatment would be vagal maneuvers (Valsalva maneuver) in awake patients. This is because vagal maneuvers alone can terminate approximately 20% to 25% of reentry supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs).

If this is unsuccessful, then iv adenosine 6 mg is given. If necessary another dose of adenosine 12 mg may be administered after 1-2 minutes.

If the drug is administered via a central venous catheter, then these doses are reduced to 3 mg and 6 mg respectively.

questions.text: The image shown belongs to an investigation modality that uses coherent light to obtain 2D/3D images of tissue upto micrometer resolutions. The investigation is:
questions.solution:
The imaging modality shown in the image is OCT- Optical Coherence Tomography.

Optical Coherance Tomography uses coherant light to obtain images of tissue in 2D or 3D upto micrometer resolutions.

Currently it is primarily employed in ophthalmology and interventional cardiology.

The image in question shows a optical coherence tomography image of fluid accumulation in subretinal space with shallow retinal detachment.

 

The following image shows OCT of a retina.

The following image shows an Intracoronary OCT image. The image shows a intracoronary plaque from 6 o'clock to 8 o’clock.

questions.text: A boy caught his leg against a solid obstacle while falling. The image shows his post repair x ray. Which of the following is an accurate description of the procedure done?
questions.solution:
The image depicts tension band wiring in a figure of 8 configuration.

The mechanism of injury described in the question, leg caught against a solid obstacle while falling, causes forceful contraction of quadriceps -> transverse fracture with gap between fragments.

Tension Band wiring is used in  fixation of transverse Patellar Fractures.

Though k wires are being used, the more appropriate answer to the question would be Tension Band Wiring.

In this, two K wires are used to transfix the reduced patellar fragments and a flexible wire is  looped around them tightly.

 

AP and Lateral view X Rays of tension band wiring.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. Lymph node biopsy shows the following picture. Which of the following is not true for this condition?

choices.text: Possible transformation into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
The lymph biopsy shows closely packed back-to-back follicles of variable areas and very less inter-follicular area. It is suggestive of follicular lymphoma.

Follicular lymphoma usually follows an indolent waxing and waning course, not an aggressive course.

Lymph node (LN) biopsy shows a nodular pattern with centrocytes and centroblasts as shown below.

Immunophenotyping:

  • The cell of origin is germinal-center B cell, so it is positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, and surface Ig.
  • BCL2 expression is positive in over 90% of cases.

Histologic transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) occurs in 30 to 50% of cases.

Note: In contrast to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL has an aggressive course, shows a diffuse pattern of growth in lymph node biopsy and shows BCL-6 positivity.

questions.text: The posture seen in the image is characteristic of which poisoning?
questions.solution:
The image shows Opisthotonus posturing.It is a characteristic occurrence of strychnine poisoning.

Risus sardonicus/Lockjaw is another feature that may be seen, but is not specific for strychnine poisoning.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT image is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp - 101 F, BP - 120/88 mmHg, PR - 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this condition is surgical clipping. 

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, by preventing ischemic injury.

Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.

Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.

questions.text: What is this approach used in the treatment of oral cancer?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the visor approach.

In the visor approach, an incision is made extending from one end of the mandible to the opposite side and subplatysmal flaps are elevated superiorly over the mandible (like a visor of a helmet). This approach provides a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oral cavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has the disadvantage of anesthesia of chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves).

The surgical approach selected for excision of oral cavity tumors depends on the size of the tumor, location (anterior vs posterior), proximity to bone (mandible or maxilla), and the need to perform neck dissection. The most commonly employed approaches are as follows:

  • Peroral - accessible early-stage tumors
  • Lower cheek flap - tumors requiring partial mandibulectomy or large posterolateral tumors that cannot be accessed via a peroral approach
  • Upper cheek flap - tumors requiring partial maxillectomy or those involving the hard palate, upper gum, upper gingivobuccal sulcus and anterior soft palate
  • Mandibulotomy - larger tumors of the posterior oral cavity, tumors that involve the base of the tongue or pharyngeal wall.
  • Visor flap - larger lesions of the anterior oral cavity involving the anterior floor of the mouth and lower gum that are not amenable to a peroral approach

Commando operation is the combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection. It is used mainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.text: Treatment for the nutritional form of this disease includes:
questions.solution:
The image shows an X-Ray that is suggestive of Rickets. There is thickening and widening of the growth plate.

Stoss therapy is used to treat nutritional rickets.

Treatment of nutritional rickets is by :

Stoss therapy - 3 - 6 lakh international units of Vit D IM or Oral. Alternatively, Daily high dose Vit. D orally - 2000-5000 IU Day, over 4-6 weeks -> followed by 400 IU per day with calcium supplements for 2-4 months.

Hypophosphatemic Rickets is treated with Joule’s Solution ( Dibasic Sodium Phosphate & Phosphoric Acid).

Renal Tubular Acidosis associated Rickets is treated with Shohl’s Solution ( Citric Acid & Sodium Citrate), Bicarbonate and Phosphate supplementation.

questions.text: The amount of Blood loss you would expect in an individual with the condition in the xray given below is:
questions.solution:
Expected Blood loss in a closed femur fracture is 1000-1500 ml.

The image shows a Shaft of femur fracture with an intact soft tissue shadow suggestive of closed fracture. Blood loss expected will be 1000-1500 ml.

In closed tibial fractures, 500 - 1000 ml blood loss should be expected.

questions.text: Identify the neural tube defect shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows a newborn with encephalocele. 

Encephaloceles are caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. The bone may be partially or totally lacking.

Based on the degree of defect and tissues herniating, they are classified as follows: 

  • Meningocele - Defect is small and only meninges bulge through it
  • Meningoencephalocele - Defect is large and a part of brain bulges with the meninges
  • Meningohydroencephalocele - Defect is large and a part of the brain and ventricle bulge with the meninges

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is unlikely to be associated with the lesion seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. It is least likely to be associated with the posterior urethral valve.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys. Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lie in front of L3 vertebra due to arrest of ascent.

The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux
  • Wilms tumor
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney
  • Turner’s syndrome

questions.text: The method shown in the image is used for the delivery of:
questions.solution:
The image shows Lovset’s Maneuver used in the delivery of extended arm in breech causing obstructed shoulders.

  • Infant's sacrum is held with the thumb, the hips and pelvis are held with the other fingers.
  • Infant is turned 90° (back to the left or to the right), to bring the anterior shoulder underneath the symphysis, engaging the arm. The anterior arm is delivered.
  • Then a 180° counter-rotation is done (back to the right or to the left); this engages the posterior arm, which is then delivered.



For the delivery of aftercoming head - Mauriceau Smellie Veit technique or marshall burns technique is used

questions.text:
A patient is scheduled to undergo a total parotidectomy with selective node dissection of levels Ib, IIa, IIb, and III. Which of the following groups of lymph nodes will be removed during the procedure?
  1. Submental
  2. Submandibular
  3. Middle Jugular
  4. Lower Jugular
  5. Pretracheal
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only submandibular (Level Ib) and middle jugular nodes (Level III) nodes will be removed. The other nodes that will be removed in the procedure will be upper jugular nodes (Level IIa and IIb).

Selective neck dissection has been used in the treatment of patients with cancer of the upper aerodigestive tract (oral cavity, pharynx, larynx), cancer of the thyroid gland, cutaneous malignancies, and cancer of the salivary gland. The type of selective neck dissection used varies depending on the lymphatic drainage and metastatic pattern associated with the primary cancer site.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about fibromuscular dysplasia?

choices.text: String of beads appearance on angiography
Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the string of beads appearance on CT angiography is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common peripheral (limb) arteries affected are the iliac arteries.

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy that predominantly affects females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. It is one of the major causes of renovascular hypertension. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing order of frequency are as follows:

  1. Renal arteries
  2. Carotid arteries
  3. Peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries

On angiography, a string of beads appearance is seen as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, and the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images. 

Other options: 

Option A: In T1 weighted images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Option C: FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

Option D: STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

questions.text: The true statement regarding the clinical condition seen in the image shown below?

choices.text: It is caused by adenovirus 3, 4, and 7
It is a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus
It belongs to 3rd stage of McCallan trachoma staging
Oral tetracycline is the drug of choice.

questions.solution:
The above image identified as the cicatrizing stage of trachoma belongs to the 3rd stage of McCallan trachoma staging.

Regarding other options:

  • Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus 3, 4 and 7.
  • Mucus fishing syndrome is a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus.
  • Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in trachoma.

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.

Stage 3: Cicatrising

  • Scarring along with active infection.

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: The following anatomical classification of pelvis was given by ______and is based on _________
questions.solution:
This classification is given by Caldwell and Moloy.
This classification is based on shape of the pelvis.
The greatest transverse diameter of the inlet and its division into anterior and posterior segments are used to classify pelvis as

  • Gynaecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

questions.text: During the autopsy of a 90-year-old woman, a normal-looking liver was noted. The following microscopic appearance of hepatocytes was noted. Which of the following cellular mechanisms is likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows brownish lipofuscin granules within the liver cells. It is composed of lipid-containing residues of lysosomal digestion that are formed due to autophagocytosis.

Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment that is due to free radical injury to the tissue. It is prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients or patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

Autophagy is a process by which the cell consumes itself. It involves the sequestration of cellular organelles into cytoplasmic autophagic vacuoles (autophagosomes) that fuse with lysosomes, resulting in the digestion of the enclosed material. It occurs in the following conditions:

  • As a survival mechanism during nutrient deprivation and stress conditions
  • Cancers, inflammatory bowel diseases, neurodegenerative disorders - due to dysregulation

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with poor dental hygiene complaints of painful swallowing, difficulty in opening his mouth, and a neck swelling which has been increasing over the past 3 days. On examination, there is a woody hard swelling of the floor of the mouth. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above patient with odynophagia, trismus, swelling in the floor of the mouth with a woody-hard feel, and the tongue is pushed up and back is likely to have Ludwig's angina.

Ludwig's angina is the infection of the submandibular space present on the floor of the mouth. The mylohyoid muscle divides this space into the sublingual space (above the mylohyoid) and the submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid). Dental infections are the most common cause.

The infections are usually polymicrobial. Alpha-hemolytic streptococci, staphylococci, and Bacteroides groups are commonly associated.

Patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. Examination of the oral cavity will reveal that the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular spaces become swollen, tender, and have a woody-hard feel.

It is treated by systemic antibiotics, incision and drainage of the abscess, and tracheostomy if the airway is threatened. 

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia.

 

Other options:

Option B: Parapharyngeal abscess can occur from acute and chronic infections of the tonsils, dental infections, and infections of the parotid, retropharyngeal and submaxillary spaces. Patients with anterior compartment involvement present with prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar pillar, trismus, and external swelling behind the angle of the jaw, and patients with posterior compartment involvement present with bulges of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI and XII and sympathetic chain, and swelling of the parotid region. Symptoms common to both compartments are fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis, and signs of toxemia.

Option C: An acute retropharyngeal abscess usually occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes which leads to the formation of an abscess. The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis (extended stiff neck), and swelling on one side of the midline. (Posterior pharyngeal wall)

The image given below shows the X-ray of the retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Option D: Vincent's angina presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. The membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, specifically Borrelia vincentii.

questions.text: A Forensic Examiner receives the following skull of a victim of mob violence. Which of the following conclusions he makes is correct:

choices.text: The victim could have suffered blunt force trauma
It is not possible to determine the sequence of injuries from fracture pattern
The victim could only have suffered from a gun-shot wound as indicated by Puppe’s rule
Fracture pattern in skull injuries are random and offer no clue upon examination

questions.solution:
Puppe’s Rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, and it is of particular importance in Gunshot wounds. But the rule is not limited to gunshots.

Puppe’s rule:

A new fracture Line does not cross an existing fracture line which can be used to determine the sequence of injuries.

In this scenario, the sufferer has been a victim of mob violence and the sequence of injuries would be as mentioned below.

  •  Correct sequence of the injuries in this would be 1->2->3

Note - Puppe's rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force trauma causing skull fractures.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the procedure shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. 

Here in this question image, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree.

The pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days. CT scan is indicated in a patient complaining of pain, tachycardia, or hypotension post-ERCP. The risk factors for the development of post-ERCP pancreatitis include sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, young age, normal bilirubin, past history of pancreatitis, contrast injecting into pancreatic ducts, pancreatic sphincterotomy and balloon dilatation of biliary sphincter.

It is now recommended to administer per-rectal indomethacin or diclofenac before or after the procedure to reduce the risk of post-ERCP pancreatitis.

The other complications of ERCP include duodenal perforation, hemorrhage, and sepsis.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: On adding ascorbic acid to a reagent and heating you get the following result shown in image. Similar result is seen on heating with glucose. The said reagent does not contain
questions.solution:
The given image shows reddish brown colour change. The said colour change has occurred on heating with ascorbic acid as well as glucose which points towards it being Benedict’s Reagent.

Composition of Benedict’s Reagent:

Copper sulphate pentahydrate

Sodium citrate - to keep the copper ions in cupric state.

Sodium carbonate - to provide an alkaline medium.

Benedict’s reagent contains cupric ions, not elemental copper.

questions.text: Which is not true regarding this initiative?

choices.text: Is aimed towards adolescent girls to provide them sanitary napkins
Targets to provide sex education to adolescent girls
Includes both both boys and girls of adolescent age group
Comes under Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram

questions.solution:
The image here shows “Saathiya”, a government initiative launched to provide a platform for communication to adolescent age-related health issues.

Peer Educators (Saathiya), meaning “a good friend”, are trained by the government with the help of Saathiya salah mobile application.

These Saathiyas act as a catalyst for generating demand for adolescent health services and imparting age-appropriate knowledge on key adolescent health issues to their peer groups.

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) identifies six strategic priorities for adolescents i.e. nutrition, sexual and reproductive health (SRH), non-communicable diseases (NCDs), substance misuse, injuries and violence (including gender-based violence) and mental health.

“Suvidha” is the program aimed for the provision of sanitary napkins.

Sanitary napkins were made available for Rs.1 per pad at over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendras across India.

The program aimed to ensure napkins were made available by May 28, 2018, celebrated as World Menstrual Hygiene Day.

questions.text: Section through the region of muscle fibre indicated by the blue arrow would show
questions.solution:
The image indicates the region of I band. It will show Actin fibres.

  • Section through I band → only actin (thin filament)
  • Section through A band (Excluding H zone) → Actin and Myosin
  • Section through H zone → only myosin (thick filament)
  • Section through M line → thick filament linked with accessory proteins
  • Section at AI junction → both actin and myosin

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: The ophthalmologic instrument shown in the image is not used for:
questions.solution:
The image shows a stenopaic slit. It is not used in corneal tattooing.

It can be used to: 

  • Determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.
  • In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit
  • Perform Fincham's Test

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of delayed intellectual development, speech problems. O/E systolic heart murmur 3/6 in right upper sternal border radiating to the right cervical region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Williams syndrome is the likely diagnosis

It occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7.

Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • Stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies).


They present with cognitive impairment. The auscultatory findings are due to supravalvular aortic stenosis.

Other options:

B. Fragile X syndrome: caused by deletion of FMR1 gene. Characterised by intellectual disability, autistic behaviour and delayed language development. Characteristic facial features include long and narrow face, big ears, hypermobile joints. Men have macroorchidism.

C. Cri-du-chat syndrome: Is characterised by high pitched cry, Ventricular septal defect and intellectual disability. Facial features include microcephaly, epicanthal folds, broad nasal bridge, down slanting palpebral fissure and widely spaced eyes.

D. Rett syndrome: Affects females. Initial normal development then loss of intelligence and cognitive abilities between 7-24 months of age.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the cell indicated by green arrow.

choices.text: Its Post synaptic connections are: Horizontal cells and Amacrine cells
Its Pre Synaptic connections are: Rods, cones and Amacrine cells
It is immediately succeeded by Lateral Geniculate bodies in order of Retinal neurons
It is immediately succeeded by Ganglion cells in order of Retinal neurons

questions.solution:
It is immediately succeeded by Ganglion cells in order of Retinal neurons.

The cell marked above is Bipolar cell.

Bipolar cells exist between photoreceptors (Rods and cones) and ganglion cells. They transmit signals from the Rods cells and Cone cells to the ganglion cells.

-> Presynaptic connections are Rods and cones and occasionally Horizontal cells.

-> Postsynaptic connections are Ganglion cells and amacrine cells.

Rods and cones are first order receptor cells. Bipolar cells are second order receptor cells.

Ganglion cells are third order receptor cells.

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina  (inner to outer)

  1. Internal limiting membrane
  2. Nerve fibre layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer           
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: What is the area marked as 'A' in the image below?
questions.solution:
The area marked 'A' in the image is rostrum of the corpus callosum. It connects the orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following condition can you use the device seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a ear syringe. It can be used in patients with dried fungal debris.

Indications of ear syringing:

  • Wax removal
  • Blunt foriegn bodies
  • Dried fungal debris
  • Epithelial debris

Contraindications:

  • Acute inflammation of the external or middle ear
  • Perforated tympanic membrane
  • Hygroscopic or sharp foreign bodies

Potential Complications:

  1. Tympanic membrane trauma
  2. Giddiness (usually temporary)
  3. Vaso-vagal shock

questions.text: The device shown in the image cannot be used for _____.

choices.text: A patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment

questions.solution:
Ilizarov fixator cannot be used for a patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment as it would cause direct seeding of tissue.

Uses:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Nonunion
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Arthrodesis by crushing the articular surfaces against each other

It can also be used for preventing the progression of fat embolism syndrome as external fixation is one of the modalities used as a part of damage control surgery.

questions.text: The type of uterine fibromyoma in the image
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Submucous type of uterine fibromyoma.

Uterine myomas are broadly classified into 3 types.

They are-

  • Intramural - remains within the myometrial wall.
  • Submucous - present inside the uterine cavity and covered only by a thin endometrium.
  • Subserous - present towards the peritoneal surface.

Treatment includes:

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid
  • Uterine artery embolization.
  • Myomectomy.
  • Total / subtotal hysterectomy.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary hidradenoma of the vulva.

It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.

questions.text: Identify the imaging shown below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Diffusion Tensor Imaging(DTI), an MRI-based neuroimaging.

It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts of the brain. White matter tracts of the brain include association fibres, commissural fibres, projection fibres, and subcortical fibres.

Magnetic Resonance (MR) spectroscopy is a non-invasive test based on the principle of magnetic resonance used to analyse the metabolite distribution within the brain tissue. It contains N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), choline, creatine, lipids and lactate.

The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

questions.text: Identify the tract marked "A" in the given section of the spinal cord.
questions.solution:
The tract marked "A" in the image is the lateral reticulospinal tract.

They originate from the reticular formation of the brain and terminate on the α and γ motor neurons in the spinal cord. They inhibit or facilitate voluntary movement.

questions.text: The given schematic image shows the working principle of:
questions.solution:
The image shows the working principle schematic of Mass Spectrometer.

In this, a sample in vacuum is vaporized in the presence of a proton donor to impart a positive charge. An electrical field then propels the cations toward a curved flight tube. A magnetic field deflects them at a right angle to their original direction of flight.  The current to the electromagnet is gradually increased so as to bend the path of each ion sufficiently to strike a detector mounted at the end of the flight tube. For the ions with identical net charge, the force required to bend their path to the same extent is proportionate to their mass.

questions.text: Given below is an image of a histological section of the skin. Identify the structure marked X.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the histological image of the skin is the Meissner's corpuscle which is located in the papillary dermis.

Each corpuscle consists of a connective tissue capsule and a central core composed of a stack of flat modified Schwann cells (Coiled spring-like morphology). They are present in the dermal papillae of all parts of hands and foot, anterior aspect of the forearm, lips and mucous membrane of the apical part of the tongue.

They are rapidly acting mechanoreceptors and are specialised for light touch and low-frequency stimuli. They are sensitive to shape and textural changes and provide the neural basis for reading Braille text.

The histological image below shows Meissner's corpuscles in the dermal papillae.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: The symbol for X linked recessive inheritance and adoption are respectively:
questions.solution: The symbol for X linked recessive is B and Adoption is C

questions.text: A  hosteller developed papules with excoriation in the interdigital web spaces, groin, and under-surface of the breasts. She tells that lesions are intensely pruritic at night and her roommate has similar complaints. Identify the wrong statement about the vector causing this condition, shown in the image below.

choices.text: Life cycle of  the vector has 4 stages
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis
The entire life cycle takes about 15 days

questions.solution:
The clinical background is probably suggestive of scabies. The given image depicts an itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The incorrect statement is that the male parasite burrows into the epidermis.

The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow. A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow. The larval stage, which emerges from the eggs, has 3 pairs of legs. After the larvae moult, the resulting nymphs have 4 pairs of legs.

The life cycle has 4 stages- egg, larva, nymph, and adult. It takes about 10-15 days to progress from egg to adult. However, the adult mites live for 1 to 2 months.

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasites in the epidermis. Clinical features include itching severe at night, superficial burrows in the affected site, and secondary infection of the lesions leading to crusted papules and pustules. Multiple members of a household may be affected, hence simultaneous treatment of all the household contacts is essential.

 

The diagnosis is made by visualizing the parasite in skin debris under a microscope. Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies
