questions.text: The x ray image shown is that of an individual with history of multiple episodes of painful swelling of the foot. Which of the following is incorrect regarding management of his condition?

choices.text: Allopurinol is the drug of choice for him even if his renal function is compromised
Colchicine can be used for acute attacks
Weight loss causes more severe and frequent attacks

questions.solution:
Weight loss does not cause more severe or frequent attacks.
The image shows Martel’s Sign/ G Sign/ Rat bite erosion which is suggestive of chronic tophaceous gout.
Allopurinol is the drug of choice in chronic tophaceous gout as well as in those with renal insufficiency(with dose adjustment).

Preventive Measures:

  1. Low Purine Diet
  2. Increased fluid ingestion
  3. Decreased Alcohol intake
  4. Weight loss
  5. Avoiding Diuretics

Treatment of acute attack:

  1. Colchicine
  2. NSAIDs
  3. Glucocorticoids

Treatment of chronic Gout (always started under the cover of NSAIDs)

  1. Uricosuric Drugs (Probenecid or Sulfinpyrazone)
  2. Allopurinol

Note: Febuxostat is a hypouricemic drug that does not require dose adjustment in renal disease. Allopurinol is the drug used in gout with renal disease with dose adjustment.

Blue cylinders are used to store nitrous oxide.

questions.text: The given image shows

choices.text: Lineweaver Burk Plot of  Noncompetitive inhibition
Lineweaver Burk Plot of competitive inhibition

questions.solution:
The graph shows a plot of 1/V(Reaction Velocity) vs Concentration of inhibitor across various concentrations of substrate. Hence is a Dixon Plot.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the condition shown in the image?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of congenital stridor
It is the most common congenital lesion of larynx
The condition may affect arytenoid cartilages
GERD is less commonly seen as airway collapses

questions.solution:
The image shows Omega shaped epiglottis seen in Laryngomalacia. GERD is more common in these individuals, not less common. This is believed to be because of the more negative intrathoracic pressure required to overcome obstruction due to airway collapse.

Laryngomalacia may affect arytenoid cartilage, epiglottis or both.

 

Larygomalacia is the Most common:

  •  cause of inspiratory noise in infants
  •  cause of congenital stridor
  •  congenital lesion of larynx

 

 

Factors increasing Stridor in laryngomalacia:

  • Supine Position
  • Sleep
  • Agitation
  • URI (Upper Respiratory tract Infection)
  • At times during and after feeding

The cry of the baby is normal in laryngomalacia. Abnormal cry is suggestive of vocal cord pathology.

 

Management:

No intervention is usually required as the condition mostly resolves by 2 years of age

 

The following image shows a normal epiglottis.

questions.text: The given image shows a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) of a 3-year-old boy. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children
Both males  and females are affected
Antenatal USG would have shown oligohydramnios
Transurethral ablation of leaflets can be done

questions.solution:
The given image of an MCU shows dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects corresponding with the valves. This is suggestive of a posterior urethral valve. The posterior urethral valve affects only males.

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are obstructing membranous folds within the lumen of the posterior urethra, which hinders the outflow of urine from the urinary bladder. It may precipitate chronic renal disease in children. It is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in male newborns.

Antenatal USG would show oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.

On performing an MCU, the posterior urethral valve appears as a sharply defined perpendicular or oblique lucency in the distal prostatic urethra. The posterior urethra is dilated and elongated with a shield-like appearance. The bladder is trabeculated with clear demarcation of the hypertrophied bladder neck.

Children with PUV who are not diagnosed before birth may present with delayed voiding or a poor urinary stream. Infants are predisposed to repeated UTIs. Other common signs and symptoms may include a palpable abdominal mass, failure to thrive, lethargy, poor feeding, urosepsis, and urinary ascites. Older boys may have persistent diurnal incontinence or abdominal distention. Physical examination of the newborn reveals a palpable bladder. 

Transurethral ablation of leaflets is done in older boys who have a posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: A patients presents to the casualty after an RTA with the limb in position as shown in the image. Which of the following are incorrect about the most probable condition the patient is suffering from?

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice the following finding. Which of the following conditions is the patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given finding in the image is clubbing, hence the patient is unlikely to have COPD. Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. 

In case there is clubbing in a patient with COPD then a possibility of lung cancer must be ruled out.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window gets obliterated. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

Specific for renal failure

Specific for hypoalbuminemia

Melanoma, benign nevus, chemical staining, normal variant in darkly pigmented people

Subacute bacterial endocarditis, SLE, rheumatoid arthritis, antiphospholipid syndrome, peptic ulcer disease, malignancies, oral contraceptive use, pregnancy, psoriasis, trauma

Telangiectasia

Rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, dermatomyositis, scleroderma

questions.text: The given image represents a theory regarding endometriosis which was proposed
questions.solution:
This theory was proposed by Sampson.

This theory is called Implantation theory.

Implantation theory - Endometriosis occurs as a result of reflux of menstrual endometrium through the fallopian tubes and its subsequent implantation and growth on the pelvic peritoneum and the surrounding structures.

Meyer and Ivanoff proposed coelomic metaplasia theory of endometriosis.

Regnier de Graaf described the graafian follicle.

questions.text: The critical path in the flow chart given below includes how many days?
questions.solution:
Critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Here the red line signifies the critical path and it includes 9 days.

Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: The Clinical Image shown is

choices.text: The most common manifestation of nail psoriasis
The most specific sign of nail psoriasis
The most common manifestation of Lichen Planus of the nail
The most specific sign of Nail Lichen Planus

questions.solution:
The above clinical image depicting Subungual oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discolouration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature.

Image of Thinning of Nails.Most common sign Of Lichen Planus of the nails

Image of Dorsal Nail Pterygium.
It is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. Fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
Lanz incision is a transverse skin crease incision for appendicitis 2 cm below the  umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid inguinal line

Option A: Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. It is also called McBurney incision.

Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

Option D: Rockey–Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified protein derivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears as follows.  Which of the following does this represent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside. 

Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with periorbital swelling as shown below. She complains of significant visual impairment and a fungal etiology is suspected. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukaemia, lymphoma and other immunocompromised states. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Invasive mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia / uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids / immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

questions.text: You observe the catheter shown in the image being used by your attending in the ICU. Which of the following procedures is it used for?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-ganz catheter which is used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter. The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. 

Uses of Swan-ganz catheter:

  • Measurement of pressures in right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery
  • Indirect measurement of left atrial pressure through pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Oxygen saturation- pulmonary samples to rule out left-right shunt
  • Monitoring left ventricle filling pressure
  • Differentiate cardiogenic from non cardiogenic pulmonary edema

The image a footling presentation with both thighs and legs partially extended.

In Extended Breech, also called frank breech thighs are flexed on trunk and legs are extended.

In knee presentation thighs are extended but knees are flexed.

questions.text: You are assisting your senior resident who is performing the procedure shown in the image. He engages you with some historical trivia and asks you who performed this procedure first. What would your answer be?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above picture is spinal anesthesia.

The first case of spinal anesthesia in humans was performed by August Bier in 1898. He performed spinal anesthesia using the local anesthetic cocaine.

Spinal anesthesia involves the administration of a local anesthetic into the spinal subarachnoid space to provide motor and sensory blockade. Another contribution by August Bier is 'Bier's block' or IVRA (intravenous regional anesthesia).

 

John Lundy: coined the term balanced anesthesia. 

Carl Koller:  proposed local anesthetic property of cocaine. 

Oliver Wendell: coined the term anesthesia.

questions.text: A 65 year old women was admitted with complaints of fever and cough with a chest X ray suggesting pneumonia. She was treated with appropriate antibiotics. Later, she develops severe diarrhoea. The endoscopic finding of this patient is given below. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of this condition ?

choices.text: Detection of causative organism/Toxins in stool by culture or PCR

questions.solution:
The findings are suggestive of Pseudomembranous colitis as a result of Clostridium difficile infection.

No single traditional test has high sensitivity, high specificity, and rapid turnaround. The diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection is based on a combination of clinical criteria rather than a single investigation which includes:

  1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus
  2. Toxin A or B detected in the stool, toxin-producing C. difficile detected in the stool by PCR or culture, or pseudomembranes seen in the colon
  3. Endoscopy: Pseudomembranous colitis is visualized only in 50 % of patients with positive stool culture and toxin assay. A negative result does not rule out the diagnosis.
  4. Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) has also been approved for diagnostic purpose as it is rapid and sensitive.

questions.text: The incorrect statement regarding the deformity shown in the image is:

choices.text: It can be congenital or acquired
There is no restriction in range of movement in wrist
Vickers ligament release can be used as a treatment

questions.solution:
Restriction of movement is present in madelung deformity, which is shown in the image.

Madelung Deformity can be congenital or acquired.

In this the distal radius curves forwards(ventrally), carrying with it the carpus and hand but leaving the lower ulna sticking out as a lump on the back of wrist.

The deformity increases progressively with age. There is minimal pain but restriction of movements at the wrist joint present.

Negative Eugenics:

questions.text: The image shows cardiac action potential graphs. At the point indicated by ‘A’,
questions.solution:
At the beginning of plateau phase, Slow Calcium channels open.


Phases of cardiac action potential

  • 0→ Depolarisation and overshoot
    • Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+channels
  • 1→ Initial rapid repolarization
    • Due to closure of Na+channels and opening up of K+channels
  • 2→ Plateau phase
    • Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+channels
  • 3→ Late rapid repolarization
  • 4→ Baseline (RMP)
    • Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+efflux through K+ channels.
  • Until about half of phase 3 of cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male patient with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings  on the anterior surface of lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The given image and the clinical features of red tender swellings in a patient with Crohn’s disease are suggestive of erythema nodosum.

The most common infectious cause of erythema nodosum is group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus infection.

Aetiological factors in erythema nodosum:

  • Infections: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, leprosy, Brucella, toxoplasmosis, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, CMV, E. coli, Yersinia, tuberculosis
  • Idiopathic, pregnancy
  • Drugs including oral contraceptives, hormonal replacement therapy, sulphonamides, and penicillin
  • Sarcoidosis, SLE, RA, Reiter's syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease
  • Malignancy

It is the result of a non-specific cutaneous reaction to various antigens. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. The prodromal phase includes fever, joint, and muscle pains, and an alteration in general health. It is followed by the development of painful, tender, nodules on the extensor surfaces of the legs, knees and forearms. It usually resolves spontaneously in about 10 days. Treatment is mostly supportive.

The image below shows erythema nodosum.

Dermatologic manifestations of IBD are as follows:

Option A) Pyoderma gangrenosum: UC > CD, runs a course independent from bowel disease activity. Begins as a pustule, ulcerates circumferentially, is seen commonly on the dorsal surface of feet and legs, and may occur on arms, chest, and face.
Option C) Sweet’s syndrome: acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in UC.
Option D) Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is often seen in immunocompromised patients such as those with neutropenia. It presents as a round/oval lesion, 1 to 15 cm in diameter, with a halo of erythema and a necrotic center.

questions.text: In a statistical analysis, the following scatter plot is obtained. What is the inference about the correlation coefficient according to the plot?

choices.text: There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to -1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to +1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero
There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero

questions.solution:
The above scatter plot shows a linear positive correlation, with the correlation coefficient +1 [rise in the value of (X) proportionately raises the value of (Y)]

The correlation coefficient can be determined using the appearance of the scatter plot. In the given scatter plot, all the plotted points can fit a straight line perfectly. Hence the correlation coefficient is +1. Conversely, if it is not possible to draw a straight line that would fit the plotted points, the correlation coefficient would be zero.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: CT scan of a patient is being reviewed. Identify the given pathology.
questions.solution:
The CT shows an air-fluid level with floating membranes (marked using yellow arrows in the image below) characteristic of a hydatid cyst. It is called a water lily or camalote sign. The most common location of hydatid cysts is the liver, followed by the lung.

If there is a disruption of the inner layers, it results in a cavitary lesion with one or more of the following radiographic features:

  • Air-fluid level
  • Water lily sign/ camalote sign - air-fluid level with a floating membrane 
  • Double wall
  • Rising sun sign/ serpent sign - a double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom 
  • Empty cyst sign - when all the contents are removed

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body. Echinococcus granulosus species is the most common.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about this procedure done for pancreatic pseudocyst?

choices.text: Failure to respond to an endoscopic treatment is an indication.
Defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.
The pseudocyst is drained through the anterior wall of the stomach.
Hemorrhage is the major complication expected.

questions.solution:
The image shows cystogastrostomy, which is done for the pancreatic pseudocyst. The pseudocyst is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach.

Surgery in pseudocyst is indicated for patients who fail to respond to endoscopic treatment.

Pancreatic pseudocysts closely attached to the stomach should be treated with a cystogastrostomy. In this procedure, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.

Hemorrhage is the major complication expected post-surgery.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient’s thyroid scan is given below. Which of the following is the preferred next step of management?
questions.solution:
The radionuclide scan shows the presence of an isolated cold nodule. Cold nodules have a high risk of developing a malignancy. Therefore the preferred next step of management would be Ultrasound-guided FNA biopsy.  

Propylthiouracil, Propranolol, and Radioactive thyroid ablation are used for hot nodules.

questions.text: A  23 year old female came with the complaints of excessive, foul smelling vaginal discharge. The saline wet preparation of the discharge is suggestive of-
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Bacterial vaginosis.

The image shows clue cells which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

Clue cells - these are vaginal epithelial cells which are heavily studded with bacteria to the extent that cell borders are blurred and nuclei are not visible.
Bacterial vaginosis - is a condition in which the vaginal flora’s symbiotic relationship shifts for unknown reasons to one in which anaerobic species overgrow.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the selective media in the given image used for selective growth of Neisseria?
questions.solution:
Bacitracin is not a component of Thayer Martin Medium.

Thayer Martin Medium selectively favors the growth of Neisseria by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with Vancomycin, gram-negative organisms (except Neisseria) with Trimethoprim and Colistin, and fungi with Nystatin.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the OPD with fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, and productive cough. On examination, there is bronchial breathing on the right side and a dull note on percussion. A chest x-ray is done. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray are suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. 

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement. The patients present with red-currant jelly sputum.

Chest X-ray shows:

  • Cavitation
  • Pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus)
  • Bulging fissure sign: Classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging; or displacement of copious amounts of inflammatory exudates within the affected parenchyma. It is seen in any space-occupying process in the lung such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and lung tumors.

questions.text: The structure marked with arrow in the image given below is concerned with _______.

Transport of neurochemicals from subjacent neurons and glia into CSF

questions.text: Universal Eye Speculum is ______
questions.solution:
Image A shows the Universal Eye Speculum. It is used to separate the eyelids for good exposure during eye surgeries.  It is called a universal eye speculum because it can be used for both, the right and left sides. It has open blades and two limbs with a spring mechanism and a screw to adjust the limbs. It is useful during intraocular surgery such as cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery and keratoplasty. Some Extraocular surgery like squint surgery, and pterygium surgery.

Image B shows Corneal Scissors. Usually used during corneal transplants and in corneal trephination.

Image C shows Vanna’s Scissors. Used to cut fine suture, anterior capsule and to perform iridotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely in patients with atheroembolic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Atheroembolic kidney disease is associated with decreased complement levels.

Atheroembolic kidney disease is more frequent in males with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease.  Most clinical atheroembolic events follow angiographic procedures, often of the coronary vessels.

It is associated with aortic aneurysms and renal artery stenosis. Systemic embolic manifestations such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss are also present, although cutaneous manifestations are more common like livedo reticularis and localized toe gangrene.

The lab findings include:

  • Rising serum creatinine
  • Transient eosinophilia
  • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • Hypocomplementemia

Definitive diagnosis depends on kidney biopsy which demonstrates microvessel occlusion with cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel as shown below.

questions.text: The correct statement regarding pattern of inheritance of the disorder characterized by the above clinical sign is-
questions.solution:
The Disorder is X-linked recessive. The sign depicted above is Gowers sign, seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. It indicates weakness of the proximal muscles especially those of the lower limb.

Here the patient has to use his hands and arms to reach a standing position from a squatting or laying down position due to lack of hip and thigh muscle strength.
Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy occurs due to mutation of the protein “Dystrophin”. It is important to the stability of the cell membrane cytoskeleton. In patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the total absence of this transcellular protein results in progressive muscle degeneration and loss of function.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a 2-cm lesion on his arm. It began as a painless papule that enlarged and, within a few days, ulcerated and formed a black crust. A gram stain of fluid from the lesion is shown in the image. Which of the following statement is false regarding this organism and the disease caused by it?

choices.text: It is a spore forming bacilli.
Biosafety level II/III laboratories are required to handle the specimens.
Person to person transmission occurs in pulmonary form of this disease
It produces a toxin which contains 3 protein.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old patient presenting with a painless papule that progressed into a black crust and microscopy showing gram-positive rods and bamboo stick appearance suggest the diagnosis of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis. Inhalation anthrax is a pulmonary form of anthrax and person-to-person transmission does not occur in inhalation anthrax and hence option C is a false statment.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive, spore forming bacillus(option A). It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of poly-γ-d-glutamic acid. 

Virulence factors of Bacillus anthracis include:

  • Polypeptide capsule which is anti-phagocytic.
  • Anthrax toxins are made of three proteins(option D)-
    • Protective antigen (PA)- Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of oedema factor and lethal factor into the cell.
    • Edema factor (EF)-  an adenylate cyclase that causes tissue oedema.
    • Lethal factor (LF)- Causes tissue death.

Human anthrax is contracted from animals that shed a large number of bacilli in discharges from the mouth, nose and rectum. There is no person-to-person transmission of anthrax. 

Bacillus anthracis may cause: 

  • Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–7 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a malignant pustule. The majority of the patients recover spontaneously, but a few may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.
  • Pulmonary anthrax: It is caused by inhaling spores seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis.
  • Intestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

Laboratory diagnosis - Biosafety level II / III cabinets are mandatory to handle specimens of anthrax disease(option B).

On microscopy, they appear as large gram-positive rods that are non-motile. Microscopy of colonies may show bacilli are arranged end to end in long chains and has a characteristic 'bamboo stick' appearance. Blood films stained with polychrome methylene blue show an amorphous purplish material around the bacillus representing the capsular material. This is called the M'Fadyean’s reaction. 

Below is the gram stain showing bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis.

On culture on blood agar, they grow non-hemolytic white or grey colonies that are rough and have a ground-glass appearance. On low-power microscopy, the edges of these colonies will show a characteristic "medusa-head" appearance due to the long, interlacing chains of the bacilli. On gelatin stab culture—an 'inverted fir tree' appearance is seen.

Treatment includes antibiotic therapy with ciprofloxacin, penicillin G, doxycycline, erythromycin, or vancomycin. Post-exposure prophylaxis after potential exposure includes ciprofloxacin or doxycycline for 60 days and three doses of a vaccine called AVA BioThrax.

Newer therapies include Obiltoxaximab and Roxibacumab, a recombinant human monoclonal antibody that is used in combination with appropriate antimicrobial agents, and anthrax immune globulin which is administered intravenously. 

Note:- It is a bioterrorism category A agent and is a potential tool in biological warfare. 

 

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

The following are the Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

S.N. Characteristics Anthrax Bacilli Anthracoid Bacilli
1. Motility Non-Motile Generally Motile
2. Capsule Capsulated Non-Capsulated
3. Shape Grow in long chains Grow in short chains
4. Medusa Head Colony Present Not Present
5. Growth in Penicillin Agar (10 units/ml) No Growth Grow Usually
6. Hemolysis Hemolysis absent or weak. Usually well marked
7. Gelatin Liquefaction Slow Gelatin Liquefaction Rapid Gelatin Liquefaction
8. Turbidity No Turbidity in broth Turbidity usually
9. Salicin Fermentation Negative Usually Positive
10. Growth at 45°C No Growth Grows usually
11. Chloral Hydrate Growth inhibited by  Chloral Hydrate Not Inhibited
12. Gamma Phage Susceptible to gamma phage Not susceptible
13. Pathogenesis Pathogenic to laboratory animals Not pathogenic

questions.text: The posture shown in image is seen in :
questions.solution:
The given image shows decorticate posturing. It is caused due to upper midbrain damage.

Decorticate posture is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain. The upper limbs are flexed, the lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended. Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture is caused by damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons. Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body.

Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are:

  • Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules
  • Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles
  • Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles 

The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: A plain radiograph of a patient shows a destructive lytic tumor that extends into the surrounding soft tissues with a characteristic onion-skin appearance. A biopsy image is shown below. Which of the following is not true about the tumor?

choices.text: It is the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children
It arises in the epiphysis of long tubular bones
Most of these tumours contain a (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation
The amount of chemotherapy-induced necrosis is an important prognostic finding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma. It arises in the diaphysis of long bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. 

Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children. It generally affects patients < 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.

Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen. Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion. It arises in the medullary cavity and usually invades the cortex, periosteum, and soft tissue.

On microscopy, sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm are seen, which may appear clear because they are rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer–Wright rosettes indicates a greater degree of neuroectodermal differentiation.

The image given below shows the histopathological findings in Ewing sarcoma.

Most Ewing sarcoma family tumors contain an (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation. Variant translocations fuse the EWS to other members of the ETS transcription factor family. CD99(MIC2), FLI1, and NSE would be positive in ES/PNET.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset headache and photophobia. On examination, she is disoriented and febrile. The investigations and peripheral smear are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this disease?

Hemoglobin - 11.2 g/dl

Platelet count - 32,000/uL

Serum creatinine - 3.9 mg/dl

Blood urea nitrogen - 38 mg/dl

choices.text: It is caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency
20% patients  will have falsely positive  RA factor
Arrhythmias are a frequent cause of death
Mainstay of treatment is blood transfusion

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) in a woman are suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Blood transfusion is not preferred in TTP as it can aggravate the condition.

TTP is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor multimers. In the absence of this protein, vWF multimers aggregate and form thrombi. It presents with a classical pentad of clinical features:

  1. Fever
  2. Thrombocytopenia
  3. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  4. Renal failure
  5. Neurological manifestations

It is treated with plasmapheresis and rituximab.

questions.text: On auscultation you hear a high pitched diastolic murmur over the left sternal border, a collapsing pulse on palpation and oral cavity examination reveals a pulsatile uvula. Which of the following pressure volume loops demonstrates the findings that you would expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option 'B' (representing image C) demonstrates the expected features of Aortic Regurgitation.

Collapsing pulse (water) on palpation, Pulsatile Uvula (Muller’s Sign) and a Diastolic murmur over the left sternal border point towards Aortic Regurgitation.
The clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of aortic regurgitation.

In aortic Regurgitation, there is loss of the isovolumetric phases of ventricular action due to continuous flow across the aortic valve i.e the isovolumetric relaxation has backflow from aorta to ventricles -> ventricular volume is not constant but keeps increasing. The isovolumetric contraction phase too initially has backflow across the valves as ventricular pressure is less than aortic pressure.
Thus, both isovolumetric phases are lost.

Also, the end systolic volume is increased in Aortic regurgitation unlike in mitral regurgitation where it is reduced.

Related Pearl: Surface Marking of the Heart Valves

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.

In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. 

Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are:

  • Antibiotic use
  • Advanced age
  • Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers
  • Immunosuppression

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a primary health center. On 5th May 2023, you took a look at these 4 vaccine vials. Vial 1 had an expiry date of 4th May 2023 and the rest of the vials had an expiry date of 14th October 2023. Which of the following vials could be used?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, only vial 2 can be used.

According to the vaccine vial monitor, vial 1 and vial 2 can be used, but vial 2 is the one that was really fit for use as it had not yet expired as on 5th May 2023. Whereas, vial 1 has crossed the date of expiry.

Vial 3 and vial 4 should be discarded even though the drug has not expired. This is because the color in the inner square has matched the outer circle in vial 3 and is darker than the outer circle in vial 4.

Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are chemical indicator labels which are used to monitor the heat stability of the vaccines and are useful throughout the vaccine supply chain. The VVMs are designed to ensure that heat-damaged vaccines are not given to the patients. They also indicate preferable order of usage of the vials, thereby minimising vaccine wastage. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: A young patient presents with resistant hypertension. CT abdomen is shown below. Which of the following conditions may also be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A history of resistant hypertension and the CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys point to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). One of the manifestations of ADPKD is in the form of Berry aneurysms.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). The patients present with hypertension and flank pain. The cause of the pain is the infection of the renal cysts, hemorrhage, or concomitant stone formation. Gross hematuria can also occur when the cyst ruptures. The most important causes of mortality in patients with ADPKD are cardiovascular complications due to hypertension, and infections of the cyst. The patients progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by late middle age.

Manifestations of ADPKD in other organs include:

  • Cysts in the liver, pancreas, spleen, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Colonic diverticulae
  • Abdominal wall hernias

The diagnosis is made using typical clinical features, family history consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance, and the presence of multiple, bilateral cysts on imaging. Ultrasound is often used as the first-line investigation. CT and T2 weighted MRI are more sensitive than ultrasound in detecting smaller-sized cysts.

Treatment includes strict control of BP using blockers of RAAS, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers. Tolvaptan (vasopressin antagonist), sirolimus, and everolimus (mTOR pathway inhibitors) have been shown to delay the progression of renal disease. More than half of the patients with ADPKD eventually require renal replacement therapy in the form of hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or renal transplant.

questions.text: A child with appearance similar to that in the image is brought to the OPD by his mother. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Lateral X Ray of the Neck is useful
Flexible or Rigid Nasopharyngoscopy can be performed
Magill forceps can be used in treatment procedure
Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UP3) is the surgical corrective option for snoring in this child

questions.solution:
The image shows a child with typical adenoid facies. Also called as long face syndrome.

Here adenoidectomy can be done. Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is not done for adenoid enlargement. UP3 is done for Obstructive sleep apnoea in adults.

The characteristic facial appearance and features consists of:

  • Short upper lip
  • Thin nostrils
  • Prominent & crowded teeth
  • High-arched palate
  • Hypoplastic maxilla
  • Rhinolalia Clausa - Hyponasal Voice
  • Aprosexia - Lack of concentration
  • Sleep apnoea in some cases

Lateral X Ray of the neck and Rigid or flexible nasopharyngoscopy can be done for evaluation of the patient. Magill’s Adenoid forceps is used to remove residual adenoid tissue after attempted removal with curettes or adenoid punches.

questions.text: The device shown in the image is _______ and the patient _______ with the machine:
questions.solution:
The image shows incentive spirometer and the patient inhales with the machine.


The patient sits upright and inhales with a slow deep breath after placing his mouth tightly around the mouthpiece.

The incentive spirometer mimics normal sighing. It serves to prevent/reverse atelectasis.

Incentive spirometer is used in post-op patients and in pneumonia patients to ensure sustained maximal inspiration so as to prevent stasis.

The simple float spirometer. It was previously used in spirometry measurements.

The image shows a Electronic Spirometry test being performed. They have better accuracy and efficiency compared to the other previously used types of spirometers.

questions.text: What is the incubation period for the infection caused by the organism shown below?
questions.solution:
The image given above is of Corynebacterium Diphtheria, the incubation period for diphtheria is 2-6 days.

Mode of transmission is droplet infection.

95% of the disease transmission is from the carriers.

Period of infectivity is for 14-28 days from onset, longer for carriers.

A case/ carrier is considered non-communicable when atleast 2 cultures from nose throat , 24hrs apart are negative.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with gait abnormalities and tremors. The eye examination reveals the following. Which of the following is true about this condition:
questions.solution:
Serum copper level is low.

The image above shows fine, pigmented and granular deposits in the cornea. This finding is characteristically seen in Wilson’s disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition due to mutation of ATP7B gene.

Although Wilson’s disease is caused because of excess copper deposition in tissues, the serum copper level is normal to low. This is because copper is mainly present in the plasma in the bound form with ceruloplasmin. Because the functional ceruloplasmin is low is in plasma, the copper gets deposited in tissues. The free copper also gets excreted in the urine causing urine copper level to be high.

Kayser–Fleischer rings (KF rings) are dark rings that appear to encircle the iris of the eye. They are due to copper deposition in part of the cornea (Descemet's membrane).

Sunflower cataracts are another ocular manifestation of Wilson disease and occur when copper deposits accumulate in the lens. Other findings in Wilson’s disease:

  • Hepatic: Liver failure, coombs negative haemolytic anaemia, acute hepatitis, cirrhosis
  • Neurologic: Dysarthria, movement disorders often stats unilaterally
  • Psychiatric: Depression , personality change, irritability.

questions.text: X Ray image of a Patient who presents with pain and swelling over his legs is given below. He gives a history of suffering a trauma to the same leg an year ago and also taking drug cocktails since 3 months prior for a viral condition he has. Which is the most common organism you would suspect?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism.

The history and the X Ray image, showing sequestrum, are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis of tibia.

Normally, the causative organism of chronic osteomyelitis is Staphylococcus aureus.

Interestingly, the history of taking a drug cocktail for a viral condition is suggestive of HIV infection and raises the issue of an immunocompromised state.

But, even in immunocompromised individuals, Staphylococcus aureus is the commonest causative organism of osteomyelitis.
Causative Organisms of Osteomyelitis

  1. Most common Organism in all age groups
  2. Most common cause of chronic osteomyelitis
  3. Most common organism in Immunocompromised individuals
  4. Most common cause of Past-traumatic/ Post surgical osteomyelitis
  5. Most common organism in open injuries


2. Salmonella - Sickle Cell Anemia

3. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa - Drug Abusers

4. Pasteurella multicoidea - Animal Bites

questions.text: A farmer presented with complaints of redness and excessive watering from the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. Microscopy of the corneal ulcer scraping shows branched septate hyphae. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Slit-lamp examination showing a corneal ulcer with satellite lesions and a thick hypopyon are suggestive of mycotic keratitis (fungal corneal ulcer) while branched septate hyphae are seen with Aspergillus and Fusarium. Natamycin 5% suspension is the drug of choice in this condition.

Treatment of fungal corneal ulcer:

  • Topical antifungals: Aspergillus and Fusarium infections are treated with natamycin, amphotericin B and voriconazole while Candida infections are treated with nystatin.
  • Systemic antifungals: Ketoconazole or voriconazole may be needed if there is a severe corneal ulcer, perforated ulcer, or suspicion of endophthalmitis.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A daily-wage worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could be the cause of the findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis.

Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. 

The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques calcify resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.

Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The image below shows thick plueral plaques.

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of severe pain along the anterior thigh after lifting a heavy weight. On performing the test indicated in the image there is a diminished response. The diagnosis that you would expect is :
(IVDP - Intervertebral Disc Prolapse )
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient comes to you with the following lesions. He tells you that he used to develop similar lesions since childhood but they always heal without scarring. His father also suffers from a similar condition. Which protein is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the image showing superficial blisters are suggestive of epidermolysis bullosa simplex, which is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a defect in K5/K14 proteins. 

Epidermolysis bullosa congenita is a group of congenital mechanobullous disorders that arise after trauma and are common over the hands, feet, elbows, and knees. There are three forms of this condition.

questions.text: The following histopathological Image was made from a thyroidectomy Specimen. Which of the following statements is false regarding management of the condition?

choices.text: Radioablation is not indicated for < 1cm unifocal Cancer
Radioablation is indicated for multifocal cancers with all <1cm
Radioablation is indicated for known distant metastases
Radioablation is indicated for Lymph node metastasis

questions.solution:
Radioablation is not indicated for multifocal cancers with all <1 cm.

The image shows Psammoma Bodies, associated with Papillary Thyroid Cancers, a differentiated thyroid neoplasm.

Management of Differentiated thyroid neoplasms entails the following management -

Post Total Thyroidectomy Radioiodine Ablation is :-

Recommended for all patients with

  • Primary Tumor of size > 4 cm.
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension of tumor regardless of tumor size.
  • Lymph Node metastasis.
  • Tumors with other High Risk Features.


Not Recommended for:

questions.text: Identify the underlying lung pathology from the given flow volume loop:
questions.solution:
Obstructive sleep apnoea.

The flow volume loop given depicts small rapid oscillations in flow during both expiration and inspiration. This type of flow volume loop is seen in obstructive sleep apnoea commonly referred to as saw-tooth pattern.

Asthma: The flow volume loop has a concave upward pattern, sometimes called "scooped-out" or "coved," on the expiratory portion of the flow-volume loop.
Silicosis and Sarcoidosis are restrictive lung disorders. They are characterised by decrease in vital capacity, increased expiratory flows when corrected for lung volume. The resulting shape of the flow-volume curve is a tall, "witch's hat" appearance with a steep descending limb.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with painless growths over the skin of vulval region since 3 months, as seen in the image. The probable diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is condylomata acuminata or venereal warts. It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by human papilloma virus 6 or 11.

Verrucous, exophytic cauliflower-like growths can be seen over the skin of the vulval region, perineum, and perianal region which are usually non-tender.

Treatment -

  • Local application of Podophyllin 25% in alcohol or Podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin for 6 hour daily,
  • Podofilox 0.5% solution
  • Trichloroacetic acid and bichloroacetic acid applied serially
  • Intralesional injection of Interferon

Vaccination - Cervarix at 0, 1 and 6 months; Gardasil at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Genital herpes - It presents with painful blisters/genital ulcers. It is caused by herpes simplex virus 2.

Gonococcal vulvovaginitis - It is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The patient usually presents with swollen, painful external genitalia and erythema around external urinary meatus, along with foul smelling vaginal discharge.

Condyloma lata - These are infectious plaques that are broad, pink or gray-white present in warm, moist body areas. It is hallmark of secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Identify the flap shown in the image used for breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
The image shows a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. It is a free flap and a variant of TRAM flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest.

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM). In a TRAM flap, the skin, fat, and rectus muscle are moved to the chest. 

If robust DIEA perforators are identified with a good caliber and dissection can be performed without dividing the muscle, a DIEP flap is preferred. Otherwise, if small-caliber perforators are encountered and not aligned over the medial or lateral row, a TRAM flap is performed to ensure flap viability.

Option C: Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

DIEP flap, TRAM flap, and LD flap are autogenous tissues used in breast reconstruction.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male complains of abdominal distension and pain 2 days after cardiothoracic surgery. Nasogastric decompression and fluid replacement are done. The CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above CT shows megacolon. This is most likely due to acute colonic pseudo-obstruction/ Ogilvie's syndrome which is commonly seen in postoperative patients.

Psuedo-obstruction can present in acute or chronic forms. The acute form is seen in medically ill patients and affects the colon. The chronic form affects other parts of the gastrointestinal tract and presents with recurring subacute and partial intestinal obstruction.

Diagnosis is by abdominal X-rays which show distended colon with the right and transverse segment of colon affected majorly. A transition point is often present, usually at or near the splenic flexure.

The most useful investigation is a water-soluble enema. Contrast enema differentiates mechanical obstruction and pseudo-obstruction

Initial treatment is by nasogastric decompression, fluid deficit replacement, and electrolyte abnormality correction. Medications that inhibit bowel movements should be discontinued. Most patients improve with this regimen and conservative treatment with serial X-rays or USG.

Option B: Pharmacologic management with neostigmine is performed only after ruling out mechanical obstruction by water-soluble enema or colonoscopy. 

Cecostomy and colectomy with colostomy are performed only in severe cases where there is bowel necrosis.

questions.text: The image below represents the change in pressure of the pulse over time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a normal pulse waveform.

Normal pulse waveform

Wave

Description

Percussion wave

It is due to the arrival of the impulse generated by LV ejection

Tidal wave

It is due to the reflected waves from the upper part of the body

Dicrotic wave

It is due to the reflected waves from the lower part of the body

Dicrotic notch or incisura

This corresponds to S2 (closure of aortic and pulmonary valves)

Other options

Option A: The character of the pulse in Aortic stenosis is pulsus parvus et tardus which is characterized by a low amplitude pulse (parvus) with a slow-rising Severe aortic stenosis (AS) and late peak (tardus). Pulsus anacroticus can also be seen in severe aortic stenosis.

Option B: The character of the pulse in Aortic Regurgitation is a Water hammer pulse which is characterized by a high(large)volume pulse, sharp rise(systolic pressure is high), Ill-sustained, and sharp fall(diastolic pressure is low). Pulsus bisferiens can also be seen in severe aortic regurgitation.

Option D: The character of the pulse in cardiac tamponade is pulsus paradoxus which is characterized by a fall in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration.

questions.text: A patient with past history of parotidectomy now presents with sweating and flushing of skin over the cheek during mastication. Which of the following nerves is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Frey's syndrome which involves the auriculotemporal nerve, marked as 2. 

Other structures marked are: 

1 - Maxillary nerve 

3 - Posterior auricular nerve 

4 - Inferior alveolar nerve

The auriculotemporal nerve is identified by its two roots which encircle the middle meningeal artery. It is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve. It gives cutaneous innervation to the tragus and the adjoining part of the auricle and carries postganglionic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland. 

Frey's syndrome is caused due to aberrant regeneration of the postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve. The nerve fibres regenerate into the nearby sweat glands. It can occur following parotid surgery, or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule. This results in sweating, warmth, and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food. Hence, Frey's syndrome is also known as gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

questions.text: The sign seen in the following sonography is suggestive of which fetal anomaly-
questions.solution:
The lemon sign is suggestive of spina bifida.

This is called lemon sign as at the level of lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by arrow). It is alsocharectaristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

Another sign called banana sign can also be seen in spina bifida in which at the level of posterior fossa, anterior curvature of cerebellum with effacement of cisterna magna can be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of the disease shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The images shows zebra pattern that is seen in Fabry's disease, which causes nephrotic syndrome (not nephritic syndrome).

Fabry's disease 

  • X-linked recessive disorder of globotriaosylceramide metabolism secondary to deficient lyososmal alpha galactosidase A activity resulting in excessive intracellular storage of globotriaosylceramide 
  • Classically it presents in childhood with acroparathesias, angiokeratoma, and hypohydrosis
  • Over time patients develop restrictive cardiomyopahty 
  • Renal biopsy reveals enlarged glomerular visceral epithelial cells packed with small clear vacuoles containing globotriaosylceramide. These vacuoles are arranged in parallel arrays known as zebra bodies which can be easily seen on electron microscopy
  • On urine analysis, oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light are seen known as maltese cross.
  • Treatment is recombinant alpha galactosidase A.

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking Bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is 4.

In the above graph,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

Therapeutic index (TI) = LD50/ED50.

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: The instruments shows in image are

choices.text: Metal catheter and Red rubber tube catheter

questions.solution:
The given image shows a metal catheter and a red rubber tube catheter.

The lack of a balloon port and balloon can be used to distinguish a red rubber tube catheter from Foley’s catheter which has a balloon port and a balloon.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with personality changes, abnormal movements, jaundice and pruritus. MRI of the brain was taken and is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image given is an axial FLAIR MRI of a patient with Wilson’s disease having the face of the giant panda appearance.

Wilson’s disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder characterized by excessive deposition of free copper in tissues. It is due to a loss of function mutation of the ATP7B gene. It is also known as hepatolenticular degenerative disease.

MRI brain in advanced disease with neurological manifestations can show the following:

  • Giant panda face sign: Hypointense superior colliculus (chin and mouth of panda), the hyperintense area around the tegmentum of the midbrain (eyes of panda), and normal substantia nigra (ears of panda).
  • Bright claustrum sign: Thin rim of a hyperintense area in the claustrum with normal putamen.
  • Mercedes-Benz/trident sign: Hyperintense pons trisected by a hypointense line.

questions.text: The condition seen in image starts to occur at intake levels of ________ of the offending agent.
questions.solution:
The image shows mottling of teeth seen in Fluorosis. It starts to occur at intake levels of 1.5 mg/L of fluoride. 

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5 mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6 mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10 mg/L

questions.text: On suddenly dropping an infant’s head in relation to her trunk, you notice the response seen in the image. Which of the following is incorrect regarding different components of this response?

choices.text: Hand opening is present by 28 weeks
Upper limb extension and abduction is present by 32 weeks
Anterior flexion with audible cry appears by 40 weeks

questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates Moro’s Reflex. In Moro's reflex, anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks.

 The different components of Moro's reflex appear as following:

  • Hand opening appears at 28 weeks.
  • Upper Limb extension and abduction appear at 32 weeks.
  • Anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks

Moro’s reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age.

An asymmetrical Moro's reflex is indicative of root plexus injury.

Moro’s is considered to be the only unlearned fear in human newborns.
