According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: From a crime scene, you recover a fingerprint that is of a loop pattern. Which of the following patterns most likely represents the same?
questions.solution:
Image A shows the Loop type of fingerprint. It is the most common type of fingerprint. 

A - Looped Pattern - 60–70%

B - Whorl - 29%

C - Arched - 3%

D - Tented Arch - 3%

Fingerprint first develops in 12–16 weeks of intrauterine life and is complete by 24 weeks. They are the impressions of patterns produced by the papillary or epidermal ridges present on the fingertips. The arrangement and distribution of the ridges not only remain unchanged throughout life but are unique for each individual. The study of this ridge pattern in the skin is called dermatoglyphics or dactylography and helps in the identification of an individual.

Edgeoscopy is the study of edges of friction ridges, which normally show seven characteristic features. Ridgeology is the study of friction ridges, which are composed of the edges of ridge units that vary in size, shape, and alignment.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a child with fever, otalgia, trismus, and odynophagia with a normal external facial examination. The oral cavity shows congested and edematous tonsil and tonsillar pillars with edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. These findings are highly suggestive of quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). 

It is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen.

Patient presents with fever, unilateral throat pain, odynophagia, hot potato voice, torticollis, foul breath, referred otalgia through glossopharyngeal nerve and trismus due to spasm of pterygoid muscles.

Oral cavity examination may show congested and edematous tonsils, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. Edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. Pus may be seen on the tonsillar region. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes may be enlarged.

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 4 to 6 weeks later. 

Rare complications seen are parapharyngeal abscess, edema of the larynx, septicemia, lung abscess, or jugular vein thrombosis. 

Other options: 

Option A: Pharyngitis presents with fever, throat pain, enlarged tonsils, and lymphoid follicles on the posterior pharyngeal wall. 

Option B: Parotid abscess occurs due to the suppuration of parotid space. It presents with swelling, redness, firmness, and tenderness in the parotid area and at the angle of the mandible. It is usually unilateral, but bilateral abscesses can occur. Due to the thick capsule, fluctuation is often difficult to elicit. 

Option C: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anaemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true about this patient’s condition?

choices.text: All forms of this tumour are associated with translocations of the MYC gene
Endemic  forms are latently infected with EBV
Tumor exhibits a high mitotic index
Neoplastic cells are usually BCL2 positive

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Neoplastic cells in Burkitt's lymphoma are usually BCL2 negative.

The biopsy image shows the classical finding of Burkitt's lymphoma called the starry sky appearance.

Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky).

The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris (the stars).

Burkitt lymphoma is the most common NHL in children <15 years.

Three distinct clinical forms of Burkitt's lymphoma are:

  • Endemic- affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla, and is EBV-associated.
  • Sporadic- in adults in western countries.
  • Immunodeficiency associated- is associated with HIV infection.

It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67). Histology shows the characteristic starry sky pattern.

Immunophenotypic markers include:

  • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
  • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
  • Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
  • HLA-DR and CD43
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumors
    • Endemic BL: EBV (+), express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL: EBV (--) and lack CD21 expression

Treatment must begin within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS prophylaxis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic alcoholism presented with severe right-sided upper abdominal pain. On examination, her SOFA score was 3. An abdominal CT was done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder is suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis.

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosis causes gas formation intramurally or intraluminally. 

This condition occurs most frequently in elderly males or patients with diabetes. Secondary infection of the gallbladder wall with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii/ C. perfringens leads to emphysematous cholecystitis, and aerobes such as Escherichia coli may also be isolated. Patients present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Crepitus is present on physical examination.

On imaging, the air is seen in the gallbladder wall and/or biliary ducts, in the absence of abnormal communication with the gastrointestinal tract is seen.

Emphysematous cholecystitis has a high mortality rate due to the development of gangrene, perforation, and other complications. Hence, emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for the management of these patients. 

 

The given image shows a postoperative specimen of an emphysematous gallbladder along with an X-ray showing air in the gallbladder wall.

questions.text: A 55 year old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination he is febrile 40°C, hypotensive and has tachycardia. Blood smear of this patient is given below. Which of the following statement is true regarding this infection?

choices.text: The gametocytes of this species is round shaped (spherical)
If more than 5% of RBCs are parasitized, the diagnosis is usually of this species.
Schuffner dots can be seen in RBCs infected by this species.
All erythrocytic stages of this species can be seen in the peripheral blood.

questions.solution:
The given blood smear shows multiple ring forms in RBCs suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum. It shows the very high percentage of RBCs containing ring forms. This high-level parasitemia is more often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection than in infection by the other plasmodia.

After the ring form in the peripheral blood, the rest of the erythrocytic cycle occurs in the capillaries of brain and internal organs. So, only ring forms can be seen in the peripheral blood and not the late trophozoites and schizonts.

The gametocytes of P. falciparum  are crescent-shaped (“banana-shaped”), whereas those of the other plasmodia are spherical.

Schüffner’s dots are intracytoplasmic granules in RBCs that stain red using the Romanovsky stain seen exclusively in P. vivax and P. ovale.

questions.text: The given ECG is suggestive of :
questions.solution:
There is depression of the ST segment, decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of Hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Hyperkalemia: causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval; progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration; disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine wave pattern.

Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Hypercalcemia: shortening of the QT interval, decrease in the ST segment duration

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with the given deformity of the left upper limb. Which of the following statements is false regarding the injury that causes this deformity?

choices.text: It is the most common elbow injury in children
Most common displacement in extension type is Posteromedial Displacement with Internal Rotation
Most common displacement in flexion type is anterior displacement
Most common fracture to involve Radial Artery

questions.solution:
The image shows Cubitus Varus/ Gunstock Deformity and that is caused by a Supracondylar Humerus Fracture.

Brachial Artery, not Radial artery is involved in Supracondylar Humerus Fractures. Supracondylar fracture is the most common fracture to involve Brachial Artery.

The Most commons of Supracondylar Fracture Humerus:

Supracondylar Fracture Humerus is:

  1. Most Common Cause of Volkman Ischemic Contracture
  2. Most Common Cause of Compartment Syndrome in children
  3. Most Common fracture to involve brachial artery
  4. Most common fracture associated with vascular injury

questions.text: The given image is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The image shows pseudoarthrosis of tibia associated with anterolateral bowing of tibia.

Factors associated with congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia:

  1. Anterolateral bowing of the tibia
  2. Neurofibromatosis
  3. Narrow medullary canal

Radiographic features of congenital pseudoarthrosis of Tibia:

  • Associated fibular bowing or fracture maybe present
  • Joint like appearance

    • Distal bone -> Sharpened

questions.text: Identify the type of muscle marked as X in the image below.
questions.solution:
The muscle marked X in the cadaveric image is the pectoralis major, which is a spiral muscle. 

Spiral muscles have fiber architecture as follows:

  • The muscle fibers have a spiral or twisted arrangement. e.g., pectoralis major (sternocostal fibers) and latissimus dorsi that undergo a 180° twist between their medial and lateral attachments.
  • The entire muscle takes a spiral course around a bone. e.g., supinator winds obliquely around the proximal radial shaft.

Cruciate is a type of spiral muscle where two or more planes of muscle fibers are arranged in differing directions. e.g., sternocleidomastoid, masseter and adductor magnus are all partially spiral and cruciate.

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

questions.text:
A 32 year old man presents to the casualty with complaints of severe left great toe pain; He has had no such prior episodes. A picture of his left foot is shown below. 
On performing an X- Ray which of the following do you expect to see?

choices.text: Martel’s Sign/ G Sign/ Rat Bite Erosions

questions.solution:
Only Soft - Tissue Swelling will be present in the X Ray of a person with Acute attack of Gout.

The history clearly says he has had no prior episodes and the clinical presentation is that of a clear cut acute attack.

The image shows inflamed great toe consistent with the above. In acute attack only soft tissue swelling will be seen in the x ray.

The other options, Martel’s Sign/ G Sign, Rat Bite Erosion, Joint space narrowing, Secondary Osteoarthritis are all characteristic of chronic gout.

questions.text: The following lesion is seen in a 25-year-old man who came to a primary health centre 5 days after he had unprotected sexual intercourse. On palpation the ulcers were painful. Suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy was present on the right side. The patient has no previous history of drug allergy. Which kit will be used for the management of this particular sexually transmitted disease?
questions.solution:
The appearance of painful genital ulcers, along with unilateral suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy, 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse best fits the symptom cluster of a non - herpetic genital ulcer. The treatment of which is kit 3 / white kit in case of no penicillin allergy.  

The above-shown clinical image and the findings are consistent with a diagnosis of chancroid.

Soft Chancre/Chancroid:

  • The causative organism is  Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • The incubation period is 3 to 10 days.
  • It presents with multiple painful ulcers on genitals.
  • It may be accompanied by unilateral painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units + tab. Azithromycin 1 gm single dose

Note: In the syndromic approach to sexually transmitted infections, kit assignment based on the identification of a cluster of symptoms rather than making an actual diagnosis is given emphasis.

 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a wrist drop, severe colicky abdominal pain, and constipation. His peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the commonest mode of occupational exposure to the compound responsible?
questions.solution:
The clinical background and the image showing basophilic stippling are suggestive of lead poisoning. Inhalation is the most common route of occupational exposure to lead.

Lead poisoning may occur by:

  • Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead
  • Ingestion via contaminated hands or when small amounts of lead trapped in the upper respiratory tract are swallowed.
  • Absorption through the skin

Painters exposed to lead-based paints usually develop plumbism (lead poisoning). The clinical features of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, constipation, loss of appetite, a blue line on the gums (Burtonian line), basophilic stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist drop, and foot drop. CNS symptoms like insomnia, headache, mental confusion, delirium, may also be seen.

Coproporphyrin levels in urine (CPU) are useful in screening. Measurement of blood and urine lead levels should be done for diagnosis.

Chelation with oral DMSA, calcium EDTA, and dimercaprol are treatment modalities. Correction of iron, calcium, zinc, and calcium deficiencies should be done. Vitamin C is a weak chelating agent.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: The given image shows a newborn brought to the OPD by his mother who has noticed the whitish lesions. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows Milia.

Milia are:

  • Also known as “milk spots”
  • Pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts.
  • Located over the face usually.
  • Resolve spontaneously without scarring.
  • Require no treatment.

Milia is distinct from Miliaria.

Miliaria is a disease of the eccrine sweat gland.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a history of diarrhoea, stools sticking to the toilet pane and weight loss over the past 2 years. The patient now presents with skin lesions, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the correct statement about the condition?

choices.text: Laboratory diagnosis is by culture of skin swab
Laboratory diagnosis is by Woods lamp
Laboratory diagnosis is by direct immunofluorescence

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of malabsorption and skin lesions, which is suspicious of celiac disease. The gold standard test for diagnosis is direct immunofluorescence (DIF). DIF classically demonstrates granular deposits of IgA within the papillary dermis.

The skin lesion shown is dermatitis herpetiformis, which is an autoimmune cutaneous eruption associated with gluten sensitivity. These lesions include intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, scalp, or buttocks. Patients with dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) also have an associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease). In most of the patients with DH, the enteropathy is asymptomatic.

DH usually responds well to treatment. Dapsone and a gluten-free diet are the primary interventions for the management of this disease.

The gold standard test for diagnosis is direct immunofluorescence (DIF). Serologic studies that identify circulating IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase, epidermal transglutaminase, and endomysium are useful for confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of these drug/drugs would cause harm to those who take it?
questions.solution:
Drug A would result in harm to the patient on consuming it.
Drug A is associated with Type 1 error i.e. Rejecting the Null hypothesis even when it’s true i.e there is no association between the drug and its desired effect but still its released into the market saying there is an association.
So the patients are unnecessarily exposed to a drug and its side effect without getting the desired effect they need.

In type 2 error even though there is an association between the drug and the desired effect the null hypothesis is accepted and the drug is not released into the market.
Impact is that the a potent drug goes unutilised.
But the drug does not harm the patient per se on consumption.

Type 1 error and Type 2 error cannot happen at the same time and hence drug C cannot be the answer

questions.text: What is false about the condition, that is relieved by the technique shown in the picture?

choices.text: Presence of a frequent sighing during history taking

questions.solution:
The technique shown in the above image is of 'breathing in a bag' technique. It relieves hypocapnia in hyperventilation syndrome.

Hyperventilation syndrome is a habit of hyperventilation due to stress or any emotional upheaval.

Symptoms occur due to hypocapnia/hypocarbia due to carbon dioxide washout:

  • Fatigue, dizziness, headache
  • Chest pain, palpitations, sweating
  • If severe - carpopedal spasms, paraesthesias, and loss of consciousness may occur. Acute hypocarbia causes respiratory alkalosis and reduced ionized calcium, resulting in hypocalcemic symptoms.

The patient has a typical history of stress followed by symptoms and frequently 'sighs' during the interview.

Treatment for hyperventilation-associated hypocapnia is breathing in a bag. The patient is told to breathe in and out of a bag so that they rebreathe the expired air. This increases the levels of arterial CO2 and quickly reverts the symptoms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI showed multiple enhancing lesions and a stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows lymphocytes, macrophages and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasma bradyzoites encased in cysts. Along with the case scenario, the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep gray nuclei.

Lesions of acute cerebral toxoplasmosis exhibit central necrosis, petechial haemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci. Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by gliotic brain.

Option A: In cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum, brain vessels are plugged with parasitized red cells. Around the vessels, ring hemorrhages and small focal inflammatory reactions (called malarial or Dürck granulomata) are seen.

Option C: Herpes simplex encephalitis is necrotizing and often hemorrhagic. Cowdry type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies may be found in both neurons and glia.

Option D: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus. The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes and hence demyelin­ation is its principal pathologic effect. The enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei contain glassy amphophilic viral inclusions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy reveals granulomas and the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.

On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites.

Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the emergency department with features of toxic shock syndrome. She reveals the usage of the contraceptive shown below. What is the contraceptive mainly composed of?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image is suggestive of the contraceptive sponge called Today and it contains a nonoxynol-9–impregnated polyurethane disc.

It contains a spermicidal agent and is placed against the cervix. Duration of action is for about 24 hours. Once placed, the contraceptive provides protection irrespective of the number of coital episodes.

It can lead to toxic shock syndrome if left over a long period of time. It is not as effective as other contraceptives such as condoms or diaphragms.

questions.solution:
The image shows a retropharyngeal abscess, indicated by widening of prevertebral soft tissue shadow. Epidural abscess, not subdural abscess is an expected complication of retropharyngeal abscess.

questions.text: The image shows a graph plotted between rate of reaction (on y axis) and substrate concentration (on x axis). Which of the statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is a property of monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
The image shows a sigmoid-shaped graph which is a property of multimeric enzymes.

Multimeric enzymes have multiple subunits. When the enzyme has many subunits, binding of substrate to one unit enhances the affinity for binding to other subunits. This is called cooperative binding. In such cases, a sigmoid-shaped saturation curve is obtained. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes. They do not follow Michaelis menten kinetics. Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding.

questions.text: Which of these vaccines is not covered in the programme mentioned below?
questions.solution:
The given logo represents Mission Indradhanush and it does not include the typhoid vaccine.

Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush. The Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB (BCG vaccine)
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae B (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

questions.text: The imaginary plane passing through the bony prominences marked in red in the image below lies at the level of________.
questions.solution:
The structures marked in red are the tubercles of the iliac crest. An imaginary line passing through them forms the trans-tubercular plane which lies at the upper border of L5. 

The abdomen is divided into 9 regions based on the following:

  • Two transverse planes:
    • Subcostal plane which is indicated by a line that joins the lowest point of the costal margin on each side. It corresponds to the level of 10th costal cartilage and lower border of second lumbar vertebra(L2) or upper border of third lumbar vertebra (L3) 
    • Trans-tubercular plane is indicated by a line that joins the tubercles of the iliac crests. It corresponds to the level of fifth lumbar vertebra (L5).
  • Two vertical planes on both sides:
    • Right and left lateral planes passing from mid-clavicular point to the mid-inguinal point.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

choices.text: Low dose broad spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis

  • Are nests of epithelial cells.

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

questions.text: The image shown below is the technique of insertion of?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of laryngeal mask airway.

Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Classic Laryngeal Mask Airway

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and ventilated patients during anesthesia.

LMA has advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics).

This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for the inexperienced provider and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx so that, once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

 

Note:

Oropharyngeal airway: inserted in the patient’s mouth with concavity towards hard palate. As the airway is inserted it is rotated 180 degrees (concavity towards the tongue) until the flange comes to rest on the patient’s lips. 

 

Nasopharyngeal airway: inserted through the nostril (after lubrication) along the natural curvature of the floor of the nasal cavity with the bevel pointing towards the septum. Once the device is inserted the flange should rest on the nostril opening.

Endotracheal tube: inserted infraglottically after visualising the vocal cords with direct laryngoscopy.

questions.text:
A 8-year-old girl is brought with complaints of hyperactivity, self-injurious behavior and learning disability. She has a prolonged history of seizures. Her MRI brain is as follows:
 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image of the child shows facial angiofibromas in characteristic butterfly pattern. MRI shows subependymal hamartomas. The most common skin lesions in TSC are hypopigmented macules, angiofibroma, shagreen patches, and fibrous plaques. Brain lesions include cortical tubers, white matter heterotopia, subependymal nodules, and subependymal giant cell tumours. Most children with TSC have epilepsy and 50% present with cognitive and learning disabilities.

Other options:
B. Periventricular nodular heterotopia may present with MRI findings similar to TSC but there are no cutaneous findings. MRI shows periventricular nodules consistent with heterotopia
C. MEN-1 may present with facial angiofibromas but they do not have any findings on MRI brain.
D. Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome present with skin lesions on face similar to tuberous sclerosis but the age of presentation is much later than TSC.

questions.text: Which of the following stain is not used in the differential staining of this organism?
questions.solution:
Methylene blue is not used in gram staining but used in acid fast staining.

The above given differential staining is gram staining used for identification of bacteria which involves these four step procedure:

  1. The crystal violet dye stains all cells blue/purple.
  2. The iodine solution (a mordant) is added to form a crystal violet–iodine complex; all cells continue to appear blue.
  3. The organic solvent, such as acetone or ethanol, extracts the blue dye complex from the lipid-rich, thin walled gram-negative bacteria to a greater degree than from the lipid-poor, thick-walled gram-positive bacteria. The gram-negative organisms appear colorless; the gram-positive bacteria remain blue
  4. The red dye safranin stains the decolorized gram negative cells red/pink; the gram-positive bacteria remain blue.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with limb in the position shown in the image. He is crying and refuses to let anyone touch his hand. On probing, the father says he tried to lift him by holding his forearm after their mock-up baseball match. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows Nursemaid's Elbow/ Pulled Elbow.

The history of lifting by holding the forearm and the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow. The arm is held more or less immobile with the elbow fully extended and the forearm pronated; any attempt to supinate the forearm is resisted. 

 

Pulled elbow: Dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament is a fairly common injury in children under the age of 6 years.

Management: Simple analgesia is provided and, while the child’s attention is diverted, the elbow is extended and pronated (the alternative technique of supination and flexion is more painful and less successful). The radial head is relocated with a snap.

questions.text: A young man presented with weight loss, and recurrent episodes of non-bloody diarrhea for the past 6 months. CT abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT abdomen showing comb sign is suggestive of Crohn's disease.

The comb sign refers to the hypervascular appearance of the mesentery in active Crohn's disease. The fibrofatty proliferation and perivascular inflammatory infiltration outline the distended intestinal arcades. This forms linear densities on the mesenteric side of the affected segments of the small bowel, which give the appearance of the teeth of a comb.

questions.text: During a colonoscopy on a 58-year-old female patient, a smooth nodular polyp is found and excised. The microscopic image is given. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the polyp.

choices.text: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years

questions.solution:
Hyperplastic polyps, as seen in the histological picture, do not have malignant potential.  

Elongated crypts, i.e., serrated (saw-toothed) or star-shaped appearance, is a characteristic feature of a hyperplastic polyp.

They are the most common type of colorectal polyps and are usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life. More than 90% occur in rectosigmoid region.

questions.text: A 24 year old primi with a history of 3 months of amenorrhoea undergoes USG.  The USG done is suggestive of

choices.text: Multiple Renal Cysts in the fetus

questions.solution:
The above USG is suggestive of Hydatidiform mole.

The USG shows the characteristic snowstorm appearance which is seen in hydatidiform mole.

It is of 2 types

  • Complete mole - grossly appear as a mass of clear vesicles.
  • Partial mole - has less hydatidiform changes and contains some fetal tissue.


Classical clinical features of a complete mole are-

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early onset preeclampsia
  • Uterus appears large for date
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries of more than 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/ml
  • USG - snowstorm appearance.

questions.text: Given below is the CT abdomen of a patient who presented with diarrhea. He is most likely to be suffering from _____.
questions.solution:
The CT image depicts the accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

Clostridium difficle infection (CDI) commonly caused by the disruption of the commensal colonic microflora, due to prolonged antimicrobial use, especially antibiotics like cephalosporins, ampicillin, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones. The more severe form of CDI is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC).

Toxigenic Clostridium difficile produces toxin A (an enterotoxin) and toxin B (a cytotoxin), damaging the epithelial-cell barrier function and causing diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation, which initially appear as small whitish-yellow plaques and later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. The patient also presents with fever, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis.

On CT imaging, accordion sign, also referred to as concertina sign, may be seen.  The terms accordion or concertina refer to a harmonica like a musical instrument. The thickened edematous bowel resembles the folds of an accordion. The hyperemic-enhancing mucosa stretched over the thickened submucosal folds produces this appearance. This is also seen when the contrast gets trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes of the colon. 

Accordion sign is typical for pseudomembranous colitis but can be also seen in ischemic colitis, AIDS-related colitis, and severe edema from cirrhosis.

The CT image below depicts accordion sign:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: The given image shows strength duration curve for excitation of a muscle fibre. Identify the chronaxie.
questions.solution:
Chronaxie is the minimum time (duration) for which a stimulus double the strength of rheobase has to be applied for excitation of tissue. It is denoted by A in the image given in the question.

Also, it is the only option with time units which is another pointer towards narrowing down options.

Rheobase is the minimum intensity (strength/magnitude) of stimulation required to generate an action potential when the stimulation is of infinite duration. It is given by D in the image given in the question.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with persistent fever and productive cough for 6 weeks with night sweats and anemia. The following is his CXR. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described along with the chest X-ray image showing air-fluid level is suggestive of a lung abscess.

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production, and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscesses usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

On physical examination:

  • Poor dentition/gingival disease
  • Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation
  • Digital clubbing
  • The absence of a gag reflex

CXR features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • The cavity wall is thick and irregular, and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate is often present
  • Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities

The two x-ray images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

questions.text: The image shows a male child with an anterior abdominal wall that is flabby and thin.   The bowel contours appear obvious on inspection and on examination the scrotum is empty. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Prune Belly Syndrome.

Prune Belly Syndrome is also known as - Eagle Barrett Syndrome, Triad Syndrome, Obrinsky Syndrome, Frohlich Syndrome.

Prune Belly Triad -

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: Identify the thickened nerve marked in the arrow in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve and the thickened nerve visible below the great auricular nerve is the transverse cervical nerve.

Nerve thickening in this case is likely to be due to leprosy.

Great auricular nerve:

It is the largest ascending branch of cervical plexus and arises from the second and the third cervical spinal nerves.

It winds over the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and ascends upwards. On reaching the parotid gland it divides into the anterior and posterior branches:

  • Anterior branch - supplies the facial skin over the parotid gland and joins the facial nerve in the gland.
  • Posterior branch - supplies the skin over the mastoid process, posteroinferior part of the auricle, lobule, and concha.

Clinical considerations:

  • Leprosy - Nerve thickening is present. The nerve is palpable over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (as seen in the above image)
  • Frey's syndrome - An aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve causes gustatory sweating.

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from ________
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopy image shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis.

The image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's Prussian blue.

The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.text: The lab technician notices a urine sample from a 40 year old male that was normal on collection turning to the colour shown in the image after a few hours. It further darkened over the next few hours. Which of the following statements will not hold true for the patient?

choices.text: Patient should have pain and stiffness of his back
Patient will have history of staining of his clothes by his sweat
Intervertebral space expansion is noted on X-rays
Treatment is initiated with Vitamin C for the patient

questions.solution:
Intervertebral space narrowing, not expansion, is seen in case of Alkaptonuria.

The image shows a urine sample that turned brown on standing and had further darkened later. This is suggestive of Alkaptonuria (Homogentisic aciduria).

The urine contains homogentisic acid which on oxidation and polymerization turns black.

The disease is caused due to deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase, an autosomal recessive disorder.


Other clinical features:-

  • Bluish-black pigmentation of ear cartilage and/or sclera due to deposits of accumulated Homogentisic acid.
  • Pain and stiffness of spine & larger joints - after 3rd decade
  • Staining of clothes by the homogentisic acid in the sweat

The X-Ray shows characteristic intervertebral space narrowing and calcification.
Treatment is with Vit. C 1g/Day. The antioxidant property of Vit. C helps to prevent the conversion to the polymeric material that is deposited in joints.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 9yr old girl developed petechial rash which initially developed on the trunk and centrifugally spread later to arms and face, she also complains of headache and fever Identify the mosquito given below which is the cause for this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical condition described in the question probably points towards Dengue fever, the mosquito which acts as a vector for this condition is Aedes Aegypti (seen in the image) It has white stripes on the body and often and referred to as the “Tiger mosquito”.

The female Aedes are fearless biters and usually bite during the day.

Aedes aegypti index i.e. The ratio between number of houses in an area where breeding of Aedes are found and the total number houses examined in that area. This index is kept at zero at all ports.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP.

It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. 

Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae.

Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance.

Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral bodies.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges
